questions.text: A 21-year-old male presented in clinic with low back pain & stiffness since 2 months. Modified Schober's test done was positive. An X-ray was done as shown in the image. Most likely diagnosis is:(AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ankylosing spondylitis

 

ANKYLOSING SPONDYLITIS

 

  • Also known as Marie-Strumpell or Bechterew’s disease.
    • It is a chronic inflammatory disease affecting the spine and sacroiliac joints.
    • HLA B27 is positive in 90% patients.
    • Sacroiliitis is the earliest manifestation with features of both enthesitis & synovitis.
    • Clinical Presentation:
      • It is most commonly seen in young males aged 15 - 25 years.
      • Most common symptom is dull backache, insidious in onset, associated with morning stiffness and improves with activity.
      • Hip and shoulder joint arthritis may occur. Peripheral joints may also be involved in some.
      • Anterior uveitis is the most common extra-articular manifestation.
  • Diagnostic Criteria: Modified New York Criterion:
    • Essential criteria is definite radiographic sacroiliitis
    • Supporting criteria: one of these three:
      • Inflammatory back pain
      • Limited chest expansion (<5 cm at 4th ICS) {not a reliable criterion in elderly because of pulmonary disorders}
      • Limited lumbar spine motion in both sagittal and frontal plane (Schober test/Modified Schober test).
    • Inflammatory back pain is classified if 4/5 are present
      1. Pain for > 3 months
      2. <40 years age
      3. Insidious onset
      4. Pain improves with exercise
      5. Pain at night
  • Spine radiograph shows:
    • Haziness of sacroiliac (SI) joint margins is the earliest change.
    • Later on, SI joints show irregular subchondral erosions in, sclerotic articular margins, joint space widening and eventually bony ankylosis.
    • Calcification of supraspinous & interspinous ligaments (Dagger sign) and that of sacroiliac and sacrotuberous ligaments.

 

 

Dagger sign

 

  • Enthesopathy: Calcification at the attachment of muscles, tendons & ligaments.
  • Trolley/Tram-track sign: Three linear radiopaque lines due to ligament calcification.
  • Squaring of vertebra, loss of lumbar lordosis and bridging osteophytes (syndesmophytes) are seen.

 

 

Trolley track sign

 

  • Bamboo spine  appearance due to syndesmophytes.

 

 

Bamboo spine

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Osteoporosis. Osteoporosis is reduction in bone mass (density) i.e. there is quantitative decrease of units of bone formation but each unit has qualitatively normal configuration. So, osteoporosis characteristically has normal calcium, phosphate and alkaline phoshatase levels. Bone Mineral Density is measured by DEXA (Dual Emission X-ray Absorptiometry) Scan and it is matched to Dexa scan of 30 year old individual and T score is calculated. WHO classification of values in a DEXA scan are T score 0 to –1 is normal, T score –1 to –2.5 is osteopenia, and T score less than –2.5 is osteoporosis. The patient is usually asymptomatic until a vertebral fracture occurs. The x-ray of the spine shows codfish vertebrae.

 

 

Option C. PIVD. Lumbar Disc Herniation is a very common cause of low back pain and unilateral leg pain, known as radiculopathy. The patient usually presents with decreased lumbar movement, paraspinal muscle spasm. The provocative tests like straight leg raise is positive. The x-ray shows decreased space between the affected vertebrae due to disc prolapse.

 

 

Option D. Osteoarthritis. Spine osteoarthritis is the presence of disc degeneration and osteophyte formation. The typical presentation of patients with symptomatic osteoarthritis of the spine is pain, stiffness, and motion restriction, which is commonly accompanied by referred pain. The lumbar spine provides pain located in the buttock and thigh region. Lumbar spine osteoarthritis can be associated with radicular pain above the knee.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The given image in the question shows the bamboo spine appearance which is characteristic of ankylosing spondylitis.
  • Out of the diagnostic criterias for ankylosing spondylitis, one of the criteria is the positive modified Schober’s test i.e., limited lumbar spine movement in saggital and frontal planes.

choices.text: Twitching motility is seen on wet saline mount
Cysts are seen on wet saline mount of vaginal secretions
It is not a sexually transmitted infection

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about Trichomonas vaginalis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Twitching motility is seen on wet saline mount

 

Trichomonas vaginalis has a jerky or twitching type of motility on the wet saline mount.

 

Lab Diagnosis for Trichomonas:

 

  1. Direct Microscopy: Wet (saline) mount of fresh samples jerky motile trophozoites and pus cells. Cystic stage not seen.
  2. Culture: Gold standard method for diagnosis.
  3. Serology: Antigen Detection in Vaginal Secretion:
    • More sensitive than microscopy
    • Indicates recent infection
    • ELISA uses monoclonal antibodies.
    • Antibody Detection by ELISA - whole cell antigen preparation
  4. Molecular Methods: Highly sensitive targeting T. vaginalis specific genes - beta-tubulin gene.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It cannot be cultured: Incorrect, as Trichomonas vaginalis can indeed be cultured and this is considered the gold standard for its diagnosis.

 

Option C. Cysts are seen on wet saline mount of vaginal secretions: Incorrect, Trichomonas vaginalis does not produce cysts; it exists only in trophozoite form.

 

Option D. It is not a sexually transmitted infection: Incorrect, as it is a well-known sexually transmitted infection.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 3-month-old child presents with photophobia and watering. Which of the following cannot be the cause? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Congenital nasolacrimal duct obstruction

 

Photophobia and watering in a 3-month-old child can be caused by various conditions. Here’s a closer look at each condition:

 

  • Congenital nasolacrimal duct obstruction: This condition typically presents with excessive tearing (lacrimation) due to blockage of the nasolacrimal duct. However, it does not cause photophobia. Photophobia indicates sensitivity to light, which is not a feature of nasolacrimal duct obstruction.
  • Congenital entropion: This condition involves the inward turning of the eyelid, causing the eyelashes to rub against the cornea. This can lead to corneal abrasions, resulting in both photophobia and watering.
  • Congenital glaucoma: This is characterized by increased intraocular pressure, which can lead to a triad of symptoms: photophobia, lacrimation, and blepharospasm (eyelid twitching). It is a serious condition that requires prompt medical attention.
  • Congenital distichiasis: This condition involves an extra row of eyelashes, which can irritate the cornea, leading to corneal abrasions. This irritation can cause both photophobia and lacrimation.

 

Other Option:

 

Option A. Congenital nasolacrimal duct obstruction: As explained, this condition causes lacrimation but not photophobia. This makes it the to the question of which condition cannot cause photophobia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Congenital nasolacrimal duct obstruction is associated with excessive tearing but does not cause photophobia. Other conditions like congenital entropion, congenital glaucoma, and congenital distichiasis can cause both photophobia and watering due to corneal involvement and irritation.

choices.text: Severe pain on passive movement
Loss of distal pulses

questions.text: A 30-year-old construction worker presents to the emergency department with severe pain in his left calf after being struck by a heavy steel beam. He reports that the pain has been progressively worsening over the last several hours and is not relieved by pain medications. The pain is especially intense when his foot is passively moved. On examination, his left calf is swollen, firm, and extremely tender to palpation. The skin over the area appears pale, and he complains of a tingling sensation in his foot. Capillary refill in the toes is slightly delayed. Which of the following is the last symptom to appear in this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Loss of distal pulses

 

Explanation:
 

Compartment syndrome is a serious condition characterized by increased pressure within a confined fascial space, leading to compromised microcirculation.

 

Pathophysiology:

 

Increased pressure in a closed fascial compartment impairs microcirculation.

 

The order of vascular compression is: capillaries, veins, and then arteries.

 

Common locations and causes:

 

Most frequently affects the deep posterior compartment of the leg, followed by the deep flexor compartment of the forearm (especially in children).

 

Often associated with fractures, particularly supracondylar humerus and tibia fractures.

 

Other causes include crush injuries, burns, infections, surgical procedures, and tight circumferential dressings.

 

Clinical presentation:

 

First symptom: Dramatically increasing pain, disproportionate to the injury and unrelieved by analgesics.

 

First sign: Pain and resistance on passive stretch of the distal-most joint of the affected extremity.

 

Later symptoms: Paresthesia (altered sensation) and paralysis due to nerve involvement.

 

The symptoms of compartment syndrome typically appear in the following order:

 

  1. Pain out of proportion to the injury
  2. Pain on passive stretch
  3. Paresthesia (altered sensation)
  4. Pallor
  5. Paralysis
  6. Pulselessness (loss of distal pulses)

 

Important clinical notes:

 

Pulselessness is a late and unreliable indicator. The presence of a pulse does not rule out compartment syndrome.

 

Exercise should be avoided as it can increase intracompartmental pressure and muscle edema.

 

Diagnosis and measurement:

 

Diagnosis is primarily clinical, based on symptoms and physical examination.

 

Pressures in the deep volar compartment are often significantly elevated compared to other compartments.

 

Treatment:

 

The affected limb should be kept at heart level, not elevated.

 

Removal of all circumferential dressings can reduce pressure by up to 85%.

 

Fasciotomy is the definitive treatment when clinical signs are present.

 

This explanation emphasizes the importance of early recognition based on clinical symptoms, particularly pain out of proportion to the injury and pain on passive stretch. It also highlights that pulselessness, while part of the classic "6 Ps," is a late and unreliable sign, making it the last symptom to appear in this condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Severe pain on passive movement: Pain, especially with passive stretching of the muscles, is often the earliest and most reliable sign of compartment syndrome. It is due to increased intracompartmental pressure affecting nerves and muscle tissue.

 

Option B. Decreased sensation (paresthesia): Paresthesia occurs early in the course of compartment syndrome due to compression of sensory nerves. It often presents as tingling or numbness in the affected limb.

 

Option C. Muscle paralysis: Muscle paralysis is a sign of worsening compartment syndrome and occurs after sensory deficits. It indicates significant nerve and muscle damage but precedes the loss of pulses.

 

Educational Objective:


Loss of distal pulses is a late sign in compartment syndrome, indicating severe arterial obstruction. Early recognition and prompt surgical intervention, usually via fasciotomy, are essential to prevent permanent damage to muscles and nerves

questions.text: Match the following:(AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A-3, B-4, C-5, D-1

 

Explanation:

 

A. Madelung deformity involves distal radius.  It is the volar translation of the wrist. It is seen associated with Turner Syndrome.

 

 

B. Haglund deformity is the bony prominence over calcaneum and the overlying retrocalcaneal bursitis.

 

 

C. Buttonhole deformity is the abnormal extension at distal interphalangeal joint and flexion at proximal interphalangeal joint and is seen with Rheumatoid arthritis.

 

 

D. Gunstock deformity is seen in Cubitus varus. It is a complication frequently seen after untreated supracondylar fracture of humerus.

 

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: The image below depicts which of the following types of cell-to-cells signaling? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Paracrine

 

Explanation

 

The given image shows the paracrine cell-to-cell signaling mechanism where signaling molecules released by a cell only affect nearby target cells.

 

An example of paracrine signaling is the release of endothelin-1, a potent vasoconstrictor released by the endothelial cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Autocrine: Incorrect. In autocrine signaling, a cell targets itself, releasing signals that bind to receptors on its own surface.

 

Option C. Endocrine: Incorrect. Endocrine signaling involves hormones that are released into the bloodstream and affect distant target cells.

 

Option D. Merocrine: Incorrect. Merocrine refers to a type of exocrine secretion where cells secrete substances via exocytosis; it is not a type of intercellular signaling but a mode of secretion.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following will not be avid on FDG PET scan? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Typical carcinoid

 

Explanation:

 

Typical carcinoids generally do not show avid uptake on an FDG PET scan because they are well-differentiated tumors with relatively low metabolic activity compared to more aggressive cancers. FDG PET scans are most effective in identifying tumors that have high glucose metabolism, which is more characteristic of rapidly growing and less differentiated tumors. Typical carcinoids, being slow-growing, often exhibit minimal FDG uptake, making them less detectable on PET scans.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Small cell carcinoma: This type of cancer is highly aggressive and shows high metabolic activity, making it usually very avid on FDG PET scans.

 

Option C. Atypical carcinoid: More aggressive than typical carcinoids, often showing intermediate to high FDG uptake due to higher metabolic activity.

 

Option D. Large cell neuroendocrine carcinoma: A highly aggressive neuroendocrine tumor that generally shows significant FDG uptake due to its rapid growth and high metabolic rate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tumors false-negative on PET-CT:

 

Lung adenocarcinoma

Mucinous adenocarcinoma

Typical carcinoid

choices.text: He has consumed alcohol and is under the influence of alcohol
He has consumed alcohol but is not under its influence

questions.text: In an examination for drunkenness, a person smells of alcohol and his conjunctiva appear red. During his motor examination, it is observed that he can walk in a straight line and can talk normally. Which of the following statements is true?(INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. He has consumed alcohol but is not under its influence

 

The presented situation depicts an individual emitting the scent of alcohol, yet their motor coordination remains unaffected, and there is no slurring of speech. This suggests that they might have consumed alcohol previously, but they are not currently under its influence.

 

If the individual were unable to walk in a straight line or displayed slurred speech, they would be considered under the influence of alcohol.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. He has consumed alcohol: This statement is true, but it does not address the influence of alcohol on the person's abilities.

 

Option B. He has consumed alcohol and is under the influence of alcohol: This statement would be true if there were signs of impaired motor coordination or slurred speech, which are not present in this case.

 

Option D. He has not consumed alcohol: This statement is false as the smell of alcohol and red conjunctiva indicate consumption of alcohol.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Blood-Alcohol Concentration and Symptoms:

questions.text: A patient presents with abdominal pain and distension. An abdominal X-ray was done, as shown below. Identify the bowel segment involved? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Jejunum

 

Explanation:

 

The given clinical scenario and X-ray are suggestive of intestinal obstruction where the involved segment is the jejunum. The obstructed bowel loops are centrally located and have valvulae conniventes (complete mucosal folds), indicating jejunal involvement.

 

Other Options:

 

Option. B. Ileum: Typically, ileal loops are located more peripherally and may show less prominent valvulae conniventes.

 

Option. C. Duodenum: Not usually seen as prominently distended in obstructions due to its fixed retroperitoneal location and smaller length.

 

Option. D. Transverse colon: Would generally show haustrations (sacculations) rather than valvulae conniventes, and distension would be more peripherally located.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a side effect of salbutamol?(AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Hypoglycemia

 

Salbutamol is a β2 receptor agonist that is used as a Short Acting Bronchodilator in the relief of acute exacerbations from asthma.

 

It can lead to tachycardia (due to stimulation of the β1 receptors at large doses), Hypokalemia and development of tolerance on long term use due to desensitization of its receptors and in large doses can lead to hyperglycemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hypokalemia: This is a known side effect of salbutamol due to its action on β2 receptors, which increase potassium uptake into cells, resulting in lower serum potassium levels.

 

Option C. Tremors: These are a common side effect of salbutamol due to β2 receptor stimulation in skeletal muscles, leading to muscle tremors.

 

Option D. Tachycardia: Salbutamol, especially at higher doses, can stimulate β1 receptors in the heart, leading to an increased heart rate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Salbutamol can cause hypokalemia, tremors, and tachycardia, but it does not cause hypoglycemia. Instead, it can lead to hyperglycemia due to its effect on glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis.

choices.text: OCP + Anti androgen
Counsel for metabolic syndrome

questions.text: A young girl presents with menstrual irregularity, acne, increased hair growth with a Ferriman Gallway score of 6, and a BMI of 29. Her mother has diabetes. Which is not a management option?  (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) OCP + Anti androgen

 

Explanation:

 

Oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) are commonly used alone for managing symptoms like acne and menstrual irregularity in PCOS. The addition of anti-androgens is typically reserved for cases where OCPs alone do not manage hirsutism effectively.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. OCP: OCPs are a standard treatment for managing menstrual irregularities and hyperandrogenism.

 

Option C. Yoga + Exercise: Yoga and exercise are recommended for weight management and improving insulin sensitivity.

 

Option D. Counsel for metabolic syndrome: Counseling for metabolic syndrome is crucial given her high BMI and family history of diabetes.

 

Educational objective:

 

In managing PCOS-like symptoms, initial treatment often starts with OCPs. Additional treatments like anti-androgens are considered if initial treatments are insufficient. Lifestyle modifications are always beneficial.

questions.text: The appearance of saphenofemoral junction on USG, showing common femoral vein, common femoral artery and the great saphenous vein is called as:(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Mickey mouse sign

 

Explanation:

 

The Mickey Mouse sign is the normal anatomy of the common femoral artery, common femoral vein and great saphenous vein on ultrasound at the saphenofemoral junction.

 

 

Mickey mouse sign: Normal SFJ

 

IOC for varicose veins, SFJ incompetence: Doppler USG

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: String sign results from a severe narrowing of a bowel loop, which makes the lumen resemble a string. Seen in case of Pyloric stenosis.

 

 

Option B: Tillaux sign is positive in the case of mesenteric cyst. It is described as a mass lesion of the abdomen which is only mobile in the horizontal and not in vertical direction.

 

Option D: Stemmer sign is seen as non-pitting edema in cases of lymphedema.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The "Mickey Mouse sign" on ultrasound is a useful anatomical descriptor for the normal configuration of the saphenofemoral junction, aiding in the assessment and diagnosis of venous issues at this location.

choices.text: Lateral condylar fracture
Monteggia fracture dislocation
Radial head fracture

questions.text: The deformity shown in the picture is most likely a complication of which of the following? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Supracondylar fracture

 

Explanation:
 

The image shows cubitus varus, also known as gunstock deformity, which commonly results from the improper healing (malunion) of a supracondylar fracture of the humerus. This deformity is characterized by an inward angle of the elbow when the arm is extended.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lateral condylar fracture - Typically leads to cubitus valgus, which is an outward angle of the elbow, rather than cubitus varus.

 

Option B. Monteggia fracture dislocation - Involves a fracture of the ulna with dislocation of the radial head, not usually associated with cubitus varus.

 

Option C. Radial head fracture - Mainly affects the forearm and elbow joint function without causing cubitus varus.

 

Educational Objective :


Cubitus varus, or gunstock deformity, is commonly a complication resulting from the malunion of a supracondylar fracture.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a perineal approach for rectal prolapse? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ripstein’s procedure

 

The following surgical options are used to treat rectal prolapse:

 

This procedure involves the use of a prosthetic mesh that is placed around the mobilized rectum, with the attachment of the mesh to the presacral fascia (anterior) below the sacral promontory. It is performed using the abdominal approach, which is difficult but has a lower recurrence rate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Delorme's operation: This surgical option involves the circumferential stripping of the rectal mucosa over the length of the prolapse. The underlying muscle is plicated with a series of sutures, and the excess rectal mucosa is excised. It is performed using the perineal approach and is associated with less morbidity but has a higher recurrence rate than the abdominal approach.

 

Option C. Thiersch operation: This surgical option involves placing a steel wire or nylon tape around the anal canal to manage partial rectal prolapse. It is largely obsolete now due to problems with chronic perineal sepsis, anal stenosis, and obstructed defecation, and is rarely used.

 

Option D. Altemeier's procedure: This surgical option involves prolapsing the rectum through the anal canal and performing a full-thickness resection, incorporating any associated colonic prolapse. Restoration of colorectal continuity can be performed by hand-sewn/stapled anastomosis. It is the procedure of choice in patients presenting with incarcerated and strangulated prolapse.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ripstein's procedure is done for its management using the abdominal approach. The perineal approach is often preferred in elderly patients with high operative risk and limited life expectancy. It involves surgeries such as Delorme's mucosectomy and Thiersch's wiring, which have higher recurrence rates than the abdominal approach.

questions.text: Identify the structure marked in the following MRI scan:(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Cerebellum

 

Explanation:

 

The given image shows an MRI of the sagittal section of the brain, where the red arrow points to the Cerebellum. This part of the brain is known for its role in motor control, and it can also be involved in some cognitive functions like attention and language.

 

Key features visible in the MRI that help identify the Cerebellum include its characteristic lobulated structure located at the posterior base of the brain, just below the cerebrum and behind the brainstem and fourth ventricle.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Midbrain: Part of the brainstem, located higher and anteriorly relative to the cerebellum on sagittal images.

 

Option C. Brainstem: The brainstem, which includes the midbrain, pons, and medulla, is located anteriorly to the cerebellum in the image.

 

Option D. Cerebrum: The largest part of the brain, covering most of the upper sections of the image, involved in various higher-order functions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Cerebellum, distinct in its appearance and location in the posterior aspect of the brain, plays crucial roles in the coordination of voluntary movements and motor functions, which can be clearly seen on sagittal MRI scans.

choices.text: Do a routine episiotomy
Manual support to perineum to maintain flexion of head
Never give warm compress to the perineum
Perform labor in lithotomy position

questions.text: Which of the following is part of the WHO guidelines for the management of second stage of labor? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Manual support to perineum to maintain flexion of head

 

Explanation:

 

The WHO Recommendations 2018 for the intrapartum second stage of labor emphasize the importance of a positive birth experience. The guidelines suggest manual support to the perineum to maintain the flexion of the fetal head, which helps in reducing perineal trauma.

 

WHO Recommendations 2018 (Intrapartum Second Stage):

 

Recommended:

 

  • Duration of the second stage in primigravida: up to 3 hours; in multigravida: up to 2 hours
  • Allowing the birthing position of choice
  • Encouraging the mother to follow her own urge to push
  • Reducing perineal trauma by using techniques such as hands-on guarding, warm compresses, and perineal massage

 

Not recommended:

 

  • Routine episiotomy
  • Fundal pressure

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Do a routine episiotomy: This is not recommended as a routine practice according to WHO guidelines. Episiotomy should only be performed when clinically indicated.

 

Option C. Never give warm compress to the perineum: This is incorrect. Warm compresses to the perineum are recommended to help reduce perineal trauma.

 

Option D. Perform labor in lithotomy position: The WHO guidelines recommend allowing the woman to choose her birthing position, rather than mandating the lithotomy position.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Manual support to the perineum and maintaining the flexion of the fetal head are part of the WHO recommendations for the second stage of labor to reduce perineal trauma and ensure a positive birth experience.

 

Ref: https://iris.who.int/bitstream/handle/10665/337693/9789240017566-eng.pdf

choices.text: Annual new case detection rate per lac
Proportion of newly diagnosed patients with grade-2 disability

questions.text: A public health official is evaluating the effectiveness of a health system in emphasizing early detection of leprosy in a community setting. Which of the following metrics would be most indicative of the system's commitment to early identification?" [INICET NOV 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Proportion of newly diagnosed patients with grade-2 disability

 

  • The proportion of newly diagnosed patients with grade 2 disability is useful in determining whether the health system is giving importance to identifying leprosy in the community.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Treatment completion rate: This measures the effectiveness of treatment adherence and success but does not directly reflect the system's ability to detect cases early.

 

Option B. Annual new case detection rate per lac: While it shows the number of new cases detected, it doesn't indicate how early these cases are being detected.

 

Option C. Treatment initiation rate: This measures how quickly diagnosed patients begin treatment but does not indicate how early the cases are being detected.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The proportion of newly diagnosed patients with grade-2 disability is a key indicator of the effectiveness of a health system in detecting leprosy early.
  • Lower proportions suggest better early detection efforts

choices.text: Compartment syndrome is common in open fractures like this, due to high-pressure buildup.
Immediate irrigation and debridement are crucial to prevent infection.
Definitive internal fixation should be performed immediately, regardless of contamination.
Open fractures of the tibia are less likely to result in complications compared to closed fractures.

questions.text: A 29-year-old male is brought to the emergency department after a high-speed motorcycle accident. He has sustained an open fracture of the tibia with bone visibly protruding through the skin and significant soft tissue damage. The wound is contaminated with dirt and debris from the road. On examination, there is severe bleeding, and the patient complains of intense pain. Intravenous antibiotics are administered, and the fracture is temporarily stabilized. Which of the following statements is true regarding this fracture?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Immediate irrigation and debridement are crucial to prevent infection.

 

Explanation:


Open fractures occur when a bone breaks through the skin, exposing the fracture to the external environment, often due to high-energy trauma. These injuries are classified by the Gustilo-Anderson system into three types based on wound size, degree of contamination, and soft tissue involvement. Immediate irrigation and debridement are critical to remove contaminants and reduce infection risk. Tscherne described four eras of open fracture treatment, emphasizing life preservation, limb preservation, infection avoidance, and function preservation.

 

For fixation, the choice of method depends on the extent of contamination and soft tissue damage. In Type I and II fractures, early internal fixation with intramedullary nails or plates may be used if managed within 6 hours. For higher-grade injuries, such as Type IIIB and IIIC, external fixation is often preferred initially to stabilize the fracture while allowing repeated wound debridement. External fixation devices, including the Ilizarov fixator, work externally to the skin and support gradual bone healing through principles like distraction osteogenesis, which can correct deformities and manage severe injuries.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Compartment syndrome is common in open fractures due to high-pressure buildup: This statement is incorrect because compartment syndrome is rare in open fractures. The communication with the external environment allows pressure to be released, preventing dangerous compartment pressure buildup.

 

Option C. Definitive internal fixation should be performed immediately, regardless of contamination: Immediate internal fixation is avoided in highly contaminated fractures due to the increased risk of infection. Instead, external fixation is initially used to manage the injury and allow for wound management before proceeding to definitive fixation.

 

Option D. Open fractures of the tibia are less likely to result in complications compared to closed fractures: Open fractures pose a higher risk of complications, including infection, non-union, and delayed healing, compared to closed fractures, primarily due to the direct exposure of the bone to external contaminants and significant soft tissue injury.

 

Educational Objective:


Open fractures require immediate irrigation, debridement, and stabilization to reduce infection risks. Compartment syndrome is rare due to the open nature of the wound, which prevents pressure buildup. The type and method of fixation depend on the severity of the injury, with external fixation often used initially in contaminated wounds to stabilize the fracture and facilitate repeated debridement before definitive management.

choices.text: Acute kidney injury (AKI)
Chronic renal failure

questions.text: AKIN and RIFLE criteria are used to classify? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Acute Kidney Injury (AKI)

 

The AKIN (Acute Kidney Injury Network) and RIFLE (Risk, Injury, Failure, Loss of kidney function, and End-stage kidney disease) criteria are specifically designed to classify and diagnose Acute Kidney Injury (AKI). These criteria help in early detection and grading the severity of AKI based on changes in serum creatinine, urine output, and duration of symptoms.

 

Current diagnosis is based on the KDIGO group criteria. Urine output (OR) Creatinine rise is considered in the diagnosis.

 

KDIGO group criteria for diagnosis of AKI:

 

  1. Increase in S. Creatinine ≥ 0.3mg/dL.
  2. Increase in S. Creatinine ≥ 1.5 times of baseline that is known/presumed to have occur in the past 7 days.
  3. Urine volume < 0.5ml/kg/hour for 6 hours.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Acute glomerulonephritis: This has specific clinical and laboratory features distinct from AKI.

 

Option C. Chronic renal failure: Characterized by a gradual loss of kidney function over months to years.

 

Option D. Nephrotic syndrome: Defined by high levels of protein in the urine, low levels of protein in the blood, high levels of cholesterol, and swelling.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The AKIN and RIFLE criteria are essential tools for diagnosing and assessing the severity of Acute Kidney Injury, which can guide interventions and predict outcomes in affected patients. They emphasize changes in serum creatinine and urine output as key indicators of kidney function.

questions.text: The formula for urea clearance is U*V/P, where U is?(INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Urine urea in mg /100ml

 

'U' in the urea clearance stands for urine concentration of urea in mg /100ml.

 

The formula for renal clearance of a substance is,

 

Clearance (C = U × V / P),

 

  • U = Urine concentration of the substance in mg / ml
  • V = Urine flow rate in ml/min
  • P = Plasma concentration of substance in mg /ml.

 

Renal clearance of a substance is the volume of plasma that is completely cleared of the substance by the kidneys per unit of time.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A child with a history of recurrent respiratory infections presented with complaints of pain around the knee and a high fever. X-ray shows lytic and sclerotic bone. His peripheral blood smear is shown in the image below. Aspirate from the joint will most likely show: (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Salmonella

 

  • The clinical presentation strongly suggests acute osteomyelitis, and joint aspirate analysis is likely to reveal Salmonella as the causative pathogen.
  • The peripheral smear findings are indicative of sickle cell anemia, a hematological disorder characterized by a variety of complications such as acute painful episodes, priapism, stroke, leg ulcers, and acute chest syndrome (presenting as pneumonia-like symptoms with fever, cough, and hypoxia).
  • Acute osteomyelitis is an infection that affects the bone and is more commonly observed in children.
  • While Staphylococcus aureus is the primary pathogen responsible for osteomyelitis, in patients with sickle cell anemia, Salmonella is often the causative agent.
  • Additionally, other bacteria such as Hemophilus influenzae, E. coli, Streptococcus, and Pseudomonas aeruginosa can also cause the condition.
  • The infection can spread through the blood (hematogenous route) or through external sources like open fractures, iatrogenic interventions, or from nearby infections.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Staphylococcus aureus. It is the most common organism to cause acute/subacute/chronic osteomyelitis, post-traumatic and post-surgical osteomyelitis in all age groups. It also causes acute pyogenic infections of spine.

 

Option B. Escherichia coli. It can cause osteomyelitis, especially hematogenous type. Sternoclavicular joint is one of the rare location for hematogenous osteomyelitis.

 

Option D. Streptococcus. It can cause osteomyelitis, especially hematogenous type.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Acute osteomyelitis in sickle cell anemia is caused by salmonella.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male addicted to recreational drugs, smoking and alcohol came to the OPD with complaints of excessive beating of heart and palpitations. On examination, there was episodic tachycardia and occasional extrasystole. Ophthalmic examination showed visual field defects. Which of the drugs is the likely cause?(AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Cocaine

 

This is a sympathomimetic features (tachycardia, palpitation, arrhythmia like extrasystole) which are typical features of cocaine. Visual field defects can also occur with cocaine (due to vasoconstriction, and ischemia) though it is not common.

 

Cocaine is a sympathomimetic drug and has stimulant effects on CNS and CVS:

 

  • Agitation and Restlessness
  • Tachycardia / Palpitations
  • Hypertension
  • Dilated Pupils
  • Profuse Sweating
  • Hyperthermia
  • Paranoia and hallucinations.
  • Serious CVS Effects: Arrhythmias, Extrasystole, Myocardial Infarction
  • Seizures, Confusion 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Nicotine:

 

  • While nicotine can cause tachycardia and palpitations, but they are more pronounced and more common feature of cocaine.
  • Extrasystole are not a typical effect of nicotine use.
  • Nicotine does not cause visual Field Defects

 

Option C. Cannabis:

 

  • Cannabis usually causes mild symptoms, and mainly in CNS (Euphoria, altered perception, impaired cognitive function)
  • Tachycardia caused by cannabis is mild, not arrhythmias or palpitation
  • It does not cause visual field defects

 

Option D. Atropine:

 

  • Atropine is not typically a recreational drug.
  • Atropine causes moderate and controlled tachycardia, but not “episodic” tachycardia or extrasystole. Palpitations are more likely with cocaine as it is sympathomimetic.
  • Atropine can cause temporary mydriasis, but not visual field defects

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cocaine is a sympathomimetic drug that causes significant stimulant effects on the CNS and CVS, leading to symptoms such as tachycardia, palpitations, arrhythmias, and, occasionally, visual field defects due to vasoconstriction and ischemia.

questions.text: Which of the following differentials should not be considered for the lesion seen in the image developed in a forest officer?(INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Kyasanur Forest Disease (KFD)

 

Eschar can be noted in the given image, and Kyasanur Forest Disease (KFD) is not a possible differential diagnosis for eschar.

  • KFD is a tick-borne viral hemorrhagic fever endemic in South India.
  • The primary clinical manifestations of KFD are fever, headache, severe muscle pain, followed by haemorrhagic symptoms like haemorrhages in the skin, mucosa & viscera, petechial lesions are characteristic skin lesions observed.
  • It is more known for its neurological and hemorrhagic manifestations but NOT Eschar.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Scrub typhus (chigger-borne typhus)

 

  • The infective agent of scrub typhus, Orientia tsutsugamushi (Previously known as Rickettsia tsutsugamushi), is conveyed to humans from its natural rodent reservoir by the bites of the Trombiculid mite.

 

 

  • Humans are infected when they are bitten by the mite larvae known as chiggers.
  • The incubation period is 1- 3 weeks. The primary lesion, or eschar, is a firm papule up to 1 mm in diameter surmounted by a vesicle, which dries to form a black crust.

 

Option C: Cutaneous anthrax (Hide porters’ disease)

 

  • Anthrax is a zoonotic infection with Bacillus anthracis.
  • Between 1 and 5 days after infection, an irritable papule develops at the site of inoculation. A bulla on a red oedematous base soon follows.
  • The bulla ruptures and forms a haemorrhagic crust which will undergo necrosis. Surrounding this several satellite lesions filled with serum or yellow fluid are arranged around a central necrotic lesion which is covered by a black eschar.
  • This is called as Malignant pustule as shown in the image below.

 

 

Option D: Healing brown recluse spider bite.

 

Bite of Loxosceles reclusa (Loxoscelism) → Target lesion develops → Development of eschar → Heals with Ulcer formation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Kyasanur Forest Disease tick-borne viral hemorrhagic fever, primarily presenting with haemorrhagic and neurological symptoms, should not be considered for skin lesion, Eschar, unlike the other mentioned differentials.

 

Ref - Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 34 page no 34.33

Ananthanarayan & Paniker’s textbook of Microbiology 10th edition Page no 249, 250, 415, 530

choices.text: Give antibiotics and send the patient home
Admit to ICU without mechanical ventilation
Admit to ICU with invasive mechanical ventilation
Consider admission in a non-ICU setting

questions.text: A 68-year-old man presents with a cough with yellowish sputum. Auscultation revealed bronchial breath sounds. He is hemodynamically stable and not confused. On examination, his respiratory rate is 20/min and blood pressure is 110/70 mmHg. Lab reports show urea levels of 44 mg/dL. What is the next best step in the management of this patient? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Consider admission in a non-ICU setting

 

The patient's presentation suggests a lower respiratory tract infection, likely pneumonia, given the cough with yellow sputum and bronchial breath sounds on auscultation. The management decision can be guided by the CURB-65 score, which helps determine the severity of pneumonia and the need for hospitalization.

 

The CURB-65 score components are:

 

  • Confusion: No
  • Urea > 7 mmol/L (19 mg/dL): Yes (urea is 44 mg/dL)
  • Respiratory rate ≥ 30/min: No (respiratory rate is 20/min)
  • Blood pressure (systolic < 90 mmHg or diastolic ≤ 60 mmHg): No (BP is 110/70 mmHg)
  • Age ≥ 65 years: Yes (patient is 68 years old)

 

The patient has two points (urea > 19 mg/dL and age ≥ 65 years).

 

Based on the CURB-65 score:

 

  • 0 points: Outpatient treatment
  • 1 point: Consider outpatient treatment or short inpatient stay
  • 2 points: Inpatient treatment
  • 3-5 points: Consider ICU admission

 

The patient scores 2 points, indicating the need for inpatient treatment but not necessarily in the ICU.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Give antibiotics and send the patient home: This would be appropriate for a patient with a CURB-65 score of 0 or possibly 1, but not for a score of 2, which indicates a higher risk that necessitates closer monitoring in an inpatient setting.

 

Option B. Admit to ICU without mechanical ventilation: ICU admission is generally reserved for patients with a CURB-65 score of 3 or higher, indicating severe pneumonia. This patient's condition does not meet those criteria.

 

Option C. Admit to ICU with invasive mechanical ventilation: This is appropriate for patients with very severe pneumonia (CURB-65 score of 4-5) or those in respiratory distress, neither of which applies to this patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For patients with pneumonia, the CURB-65 score is a useful tool for determining the appropriate level of care. A score of 2 typically indicates the need for inpatient treatment in a non-ICU setting.

questions.text: Glucosamine supplementation is given in:(AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Arthritis

 

TREATMENT OF OSTEOARTHRITIS

 

  • Maintain movement and muscle strength by physiotherapy and graded muscle exercise.
  • Protects the joint from overload by giving rest and weight reduction.
  • Correction of deformities if present.
  • Thermal modalities, analgesic medication, wedged insoles, orthosis and arthroscopic debridement and lavage.
  • Progressive joint destruction require joint replacement in elderly and HTO in young.
  • Stages of osteoarthritis:

 

 

  • Classification system and stage-wise management for osteoarthritis (OA) knee:
    • Initial treatment is always conservative (exercise and glucosamine are preferred).
    • Clinical picture is more significant than radiology or X-ray changes.
    • If activities of daily living are affected, surgery is advised.
    • Surgery for young patients is high tibial osteotomy (HTO) (if not contraindicated), if contraindicated, total knee replacement (TKR) is performed.
    • Surgery for elderly (> 65 years) is TKR.
    • Usually for stage 2 onwards in elderly, TKR is finally carried out.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Glucosamine supplementations are given in the treatment of osteoarthritis.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presented to the OPD with painful genital ulcers. Which of the following can cause a painful ulcer on the glans penis? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Chancroid

 

Painful genital ulcer is caused by Chancroid.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Syphilis: The primary lesion of syphilis, known as a chancre, is typically painless. It is caused by the bacterium Treponema pallidum and usually presents as a firm, round, and painless ulcer.

 

Option B. Chlamydia: Chlamydia trachomatis infection can cause genital ulcers but these are generally painless and associated with lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV). Chlamydia can cause urethritis, cervicitis, and other non-ulcerative conditions but is not typically associated with painful genital ulcers.

 

Option D. Lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV): LGV is a chronic infection of the lymphatic system caused by certain serotypes of Chlamydia trachomatis. The primary lesion is usually a painless genital ulcer or papule, which may go unnoticed by the patient.

 

Educational Objective

choices.text: Call the infection control team of the hospital

questions.text: You're an intern in a bustling hospital laboratory. As you're overseeing the day's activities, you notice that a newly appointed technician accidentally spills a blood sample on the floor. The technician, looking panicked, turns to you for guidance. Given the potential risks associated with blood spills, what is the most immediate and appropriate action you should instruct the technician to take? [AIIMS NOV 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Clean with absorbable material

 

  • In this situation, the next crucial action to take is to utilize absorbent material for cleaning up the spilled blood. Once the cleaning is complete, the used absorbent material should be disposed of in the designated yellow bin. Subsequently, a sodium hypochlorite solution is employed to thoroughly decontaminate the affected surface. The specific concentrations of sodium hypochlorite employed are as follows:
    • < 10 mL blood spill - 1:100 dilution to decontaminate non-porous surfaces
    • >10 mL blood spill or culture spill - 1:10 dilution for the first application, followed by 1:100 dilution

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Call the infection control team of the hospital: While important, this is not the immediate action to take to contain the spill.

 

Option B. Mop it: Mopping without proper absorbent material and decontamination procedures could spread the contamination.

 

Option C. Cover it with 1% sodium hypochlorite: This step should follow the initial clean-up with absorbent material to ensure thorough decontamination.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hypochlorites in Hospital waste Management

 

  • Disinfection of countertops and floors
  • Decontamination of blood spills
  • Irrigating agent in endodontic treatment
  • Disinfectant for manikins, laundry, dental appliances, hydrotherapy tanks
  • Treatment of liquid medical waste before disposal
  • Decontaminating water distribution systems in dialysis

questions.text: Identify the given sign:(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Popeye sign

 

  • This image shows typical finding on physical examination, which is caused by bulging of the biceps muscle belly after rupture of the biceps tendon, known as Popeye sign or Popeye deformity.
  • The Popeye is a cartoon character with bulging muscles, hence its name.

 

POPEYE SIGN

 

  • Etiology:
    • Due to sudden eccentric biomechanical load is applied with the forearm flexed and supinated, which can cause the rupture of either the proximal or the distal tendon junctions.
       
  • Risk factors: 
    • Older age
    • Smoking habit
    • Usage of certain drugs (corticosteroids, statins).
    • Shoulder overuse (sports or work-related activities).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Inverted champagne bottle sign. This sign is seen in Lipodermatosclerosis, also referred to as sclerosing panniculitis or hypodermitis sclerodermaformis, which is a persistent inflammatory disorder characterized by the development of subcutaneous fibrosis and induration of the skin of the lower extremities. The chronic phase of lipodermatosclerosis is characterized by well-defined, circumferential, thick, darkly pigmented, non-tender plaques. These plaques are described as having a firm, “woody” induration, and the sclerotic change with circumferential narrowing of the lower leg and concurrent proximal and distal edema, that produces the classic “inverted champagne bottle” appearance of the lower extremity. The rounded cork of the champagne bottle is symbolic of the edematous foot, the central fibrosis around the ankle represents the neck, and the bottle's body embodies the lymphedema proximal to the area of constriction.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The image shown in the question is called Popeye Sign, which is visible on elbow flexion due to bicipital tendonitis.

choices.text: Start with palmar flexion, followed by traction, then ulnar deviation, and finish with application of plaster of Paris
Begin with traction, proceed with ulnar deviation, followed by palmar flexion, and then apply plaster of Paris
Perform traction first, then palmar flexion, followed by ulnar deviation, and finally apply the plaster of Paris
Apply ulnar deviation initially, followed by traction, then palmar flexion, and end with the application of plaster of Paris

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman presents to the emergency department after slipping and falling on her outstretched hand. She complains of severe pain and swelling in her right wrist, with visible deformity. X-rays confirm a distal radius fracture with dorsal angulation, typical of a Colles' fracture. The orthopedic team plans to perform closed reduction and apply a cast. What is the correct sequence of steps for managing this fracture?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Perform traction first, then palmar flexion, followed by ulnar deviation, and finally apply the plaster of Paris

 

Explanation:


The correct sequence for managing a Colles' fracture through closed reduction, as described in the provided paragraph, is:

 

  • Traction: The first step is to disimpact the fragments. This is achieved by firm longitudinal traction to the hand against counter-traction by an assistant who grasps the arm above the flexed elbow. This step restores length to the radius and disengages the fractured bone ends.
  • Palmar flexion: The surgeon presses the distal fragment into palmar flexion using the thumb. This maneuver corrects the dorsal angulation of the distal fragment, which is characteristic of the "dinner fork" deformity seen in Colles' fractures.
  • Ulnar deviation: As the palmar flexion is applied, the patient's hand is drawn into ulnar deviation. This step corrects the radial deviation typically seen in these fractures and restores normal radial inclination.
  • Application of plaster of Paris: Once the reduction is achieved, a plaster cast is applied extending from below the elbow to the metacarpal heads. The cast maintains the corrected position of pronation, palmar flexion, and ulnar deviation.

 

This sequence directly addresses the typical deformities seen in a Colles' fracture: dorsal displacement of the distal fragment, volar angulation of the distal intact radius, and radial shortening.

 

Other options:

 

The other options (A, B, and D) are incorrect because they do not follow the proper sequence described in the provided information. Traction must be the first step to disimpact the fragments before any other maneuvers are attempted.

 

Educational Objective:


Steps of cast application in Colles’s fracture

 

Traction

↓

Palmar flexion

↓

Ulnar deviation

↓

Application of plaster of Paris

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents to the trauma center after RTA with shortness of breath. The supine CXR is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hemothorax

 

The provided supine chest X-ray (CXR) shows a generalized opacity throughout the left hemithorax, which is characteristic of a hemothorax. In a trauma setting, chest X-rays are often taken in the supine position because the patient cannot stand. In this position, the fluid from a hemothorax gravitates and spreads out across the thoracic cavity, leading to a uniform opacity on the affected side.

 

Hemothorax, which is the accumulation of blood in the pleural space, often occurs due to trauma and presents with symptoms of shortness of breath. The key radiographic feature on a supine CXR is the diffuse opacity without a typical meniscus sign, which is seen in erect chest X-rays.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pneumothorax: This condition presents with hyperlucency (increased radiolucency) in the affected hemithorax. In a supine CXR, a deep sulcus sign might be seen, but there is no hyperlucency present in the image, ruling out pneumothorax.

 

Option C. Pulmonary contusion: Pulmonary contusions appear as localized areas of consolidation. They do not typically cause uniform opacity throughout an entire hemithorax as seen in this image.

 

Option D. Diaphragm injury: Diaphragm injuries can result in the presence of bowel loops within the thoracic cavity, which is not evident in this image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a supine chest X-ray of a trauma patient, a hemothorax presents as a diffuse opacity throughout the affected hemithorax due to the gravitational spread of blood in the pleural space.

questions.text: An old lady complains of chronic backpain since a few months. X-ray is shown below. What is the probable diagnosis?( NEET PG 2019 )
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Osteoporosis

 

The image shows Codfish Vertebra seen in Osteoporosis.

 

OSTEOPOROSIS

 

Osteoporosis is reduction in bone mass (density) i.e., there is quantitative decrease of units of bone formation but each unit has qualitatively normal configuration. So, osteoporosis characteristically has normal calcium, phosphate and alkaline phosphatase levels.

 

Bone Mineral Density is measured by DEXA (Dual Emission X-ray Absorptiometry) Scan and it is matched to DEXA scan of 30-year-old individual of the same sex and T score is calculated.

 

 

Etiology of Osteoporosis:

 

 

Imaging

 

  • Radiological features are loss of vertical height of vertebrae (collapse) and codfish appearance (concave superior and inferior surfaces) of vertebrae.
  • Singh’s Index is used for osteoporosis grading.

 

Treatment:

 

Drugs used in osteoporosis are:

 

  1. Inhibit resorption: Bisphosphonates (drug of choice), Denosumab, calcitonin, estrogen, SERMS, gallium nitrate.
  2. Stimulate formation: Teriparatide (PTH analogue), calcium, calcitriol, fluorides.
  3. Both actions: Strontium ranelate

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Spondylolysis: Incorrect, as spondylolysis refers to a defect or fracture of the pars interarticularis of the vertebrae, not typically associated with the changes seen in the X-ray provided.

 

Option C. Spondylolisthesis: Incorrect, this condition involves the forward slippage of one vertebra over the one beneath it, which would show distinct alignment changes not described in the X-ray findings.

 

Option D. Osteopetrosis: Incorrect, as osteopetrosis is a condition characterized by the abnormal density and sclerosis of bone, quite the opposite of what is observed in osteoporosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Osteoporosis is a condition marked by a decrease in bone density and mass, leading to structural weakening of the bone and increased risk of fractures. Diagnostic imaging such as X-rays can show characteristic changes like "Codfish Vertebra" and is further confirmed by measuring bone mineral density through a DEXA scan. Treatment focuses on inhibiting bone resorption and/or stimulating bone formation through various pharmacological agents.

questions.text: A muscle is attached to the area marked in the given image. What is the action of this muscle on the hip joint?(AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Extension and lateral rotation

 

Explanation:

 

The gluteal tuberosity is indicated by the marked area in the photograph. The gluteus maximus, which is implanted here, produces lateral rotation and extension of the hip joint. Extension involves increasing the angle between the femur and the pelvis, essentially the opposite of flexion. Lateral rotation, refers to turning the anterior aspect of the femur away from the midline.

 

Three-quarters of the gluteus maximus attach to the iliotibial tract, while one-fourth attach to the gluteal tuberosity (marked in image). The inferior gluteal nerve supplies it. At the hip joint, it serves as the primary extensor of the lower limb. Abduction and lateral rotation are additional effects.

 

 

Other Options :

 

Option A. Flexion and medial rotation:

 

  • Flexion is the movement of bending the joint, resulting in a decrease of the angle between the femur and the pelvis. Medial rotation involves turning the anterior aspect of the femur inwards, toward the midline.
  • The gluteus maximus is not primarily responsible for these actions. Instead, other muscles, such as the iliopsoas and anterior fibers of the gluteus medius and minimus, play roles in hip flexion and medial rotation.

 

Option B. Adduction and lateral rotation:

 

  • Adduction involves drawing the limb toward the midline of the body, while lateral rotation refers to turning the anterior aspect of the femur away from the midline.
  • While the gluteus maximus does have fibers that can contribute to lateral rotation, it's not a primary adductor of the hip. Instead, the hip adductors (like adductor longus, adductor brevis, adductor magnus) primarily mediate adduction

 

Option C. Abduction and medial rotation:

 

  • Abduction involves moving the limb away from the midline, and as mentioned above, medial rotation involves turning the anterior aspect of the femur inwards.
  • The gluteus maximus is not a primary abductor or medial rotator of the hip. The gluteus medius and minimus are the primary muscles responsible for hip abduction, and various other muscles, including anterior fibers of the gluteus medius and minimus, contribute to medial rotation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The gluteus maximus is a primary extensor and lateral rotator of the hip joint. When you stand up from a seated position, climb stairs, or rise from a squat, the gluteus maximus is heavily involved in extending the hip.

questions.text: In osteoporosis, serum calcium and alkaline phosphatase levels are usually:(INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Normal

 

OSTEOPOROSIS (V > H > C)

 

  • Osteoporosis is reduction in bone mass (density) i.e., there is quantitative decrease of units of bone formation but each unit has qualitatively normal configuration.
  • Bone mineral density is measured by DEXA scan (65 years onwards)
  • Normal Ca2+, PO‑4, ALP
  • Hemiplegic – Humerus maximum loss of bone mineral density

 

 

  • Radiological Investigation: 
    • Quantitative CT is a newer imaging technique that can be used to detect osteoporosis
    • Radiological features are loss of vertical height of vertebrae (collapse) and codfish appearance (concave superior and inferior surfaces) of vertebrae.

 

 

Codfish vertebrae

 

  • Treatment:
    • Estrogen
    • Bisphosphonates – Increases hip fracture
    • Calcitonin
    • Low dose PTH – Stimulates osteoblasts

 

Educational objective:

 

  • In osteoporosis, the serum calcium and alkaline phosphatase levels remains normal. The bone density is decreased on the DEXA scan.

questions.text: Given the radiograph of a 13-year-old child who presented with fall on elbow. Which of the following bone is fractured? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Humerus

 

  • The image shows fracture of the upper end of humerus.

 

PROXIMAL HUMERUS FRACTURE

 

  • Approximately 40% of metaphyseal proximal humerus fractures are non- or minimally displaced and more commonly require operative treatment as compared to epiphyseal fractures.
  • The peak of these fractures occurs between ages of 10-14 and again at 80-84 years with males more affected.
  • Proximal humerus fractures most often occur upon falling backwards onto an outstretched hand with an extended elbow and externally rotated shoulder or through direct traumatic impact to the shoulder. 
  • The Neer-Horowitz system is the most widely used classification system for proximal humerus fractures in children and is graded by severity of displacement.

 

 

  • On examination, there may be swelling, tenderness, visible deformity, and unwillingness to move the shoulder by holding the arm close to the body.
  • Associated injuries to the brachial plexus, clavicle, and scapula should not be missed.
  • Standard radiographs of the shoulder including AP, and axillary views are generally sufficient to characterize the fracture morphology.
  • The majority of proximal humerus fractures in children can be treated successfully with non-operative management due to the immense remodelling potential of the physis.
  • Neer-Horowitz grade I/II can be successfully treated non-operatively with immobilization in a hanging arm/shoulder spica cast and a sling for 3-4 weeks.
  • Operative treatment should be considered in Neer-Horowitz grade III and IV fractures and greater fracture angulation in older children.
  • Failure of closed reduction should be addressed with open reduction.
  • Fixation options include percutaneous pinning, intramedullary nails, cannulated screws, and plates.

 

 

  • Percutaneous pinning remains the most commonly used fixation strategy.
  • Prognosis in children are generally excellent with both non-operative and operative treatment. 
  • Complications are rare.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Clavicle. The clavicle is one of the most common fractured bones in children. These heal quickly and recover fully. Injuries are usually the result of a fall on an outstretched hand with the force transmitted up the arm. A direct blow to the outer end of the clavicle can be associated with distal third injuries and acromioclavicular joint disruption. The vast majority present with pain, swelling and deformity along the line of the clavicle, and a history of a fall onto an outstretched arm. Fractures of the medial third are usually the result of high impact blunt force to the anterior chest (such as in a motor vehicle accident), and can be associated with neurovascular, pulmonary and cardiac (rare) injuries. Careful airway protection and neurovascular assessment is required. Vascular assessment of the arm should also be performed as the subclavian artery runs close to the clavicle in the middle third. Standard AP with 15 degrees cephalic tilt x-ray of the clavicle will show the fracture in two planes and define displacement. The majority of clavicle fractures are easily managed with a sling and analgesia.

 

 

Option C. Scapula. Scapula fractures are uncommon in children. Scapular body fractures are usually the result of high-energy trauma such as motor vehicle collisions or falls. There is a high incidence of associated injuries including other shoulder girdle fractures, rib fractures, head injury, and lung injury, such as pneumothorax or pulmonary contusion. Glenoid fractures are often due to a direct blow to the lateral shoulder or a fall onto a flexed elbow with the humeral head being driven into the glenoid. The position of the arm dictates whether an anterior or posterior rim fracture occurs. Similarly, acromion fractures are usually due to a direct blow to the lateral shoulder. Coracoid fractures are usually an avulsive injury resulting from pull of the acromioclavicular ligaments or the conjoint tendon. Scapulothoracic dissociation is often due to a severe traction injury. The primary symptom is often pain about the shoulder or back and difficulty with motion. Numbness or weakness may be present with a concomitant brachial plexus injury. The majority of fractures are treated non-operatively. Treatment includes immobilization for 3-4 weeks followed by pendulum exercises and protected range of motion. 

 

Option D. Ribs. Rib fracture in children is caused by a high force injury. Ribs 1-3 are the hardest to break. Ribs 4-10 are typically the most vulnerable while ribs 11-12 are more mobile and therefore, more difficult to break. Since children tend to have more elastic ribs than adults, children are less likely to sustain rib fractures. Therefore, children with rib fractures is a sign of significant trauma and should warrant an investigation of possible child abuse. The physical exam may reveal chest wall bruising, along with bony tenderness to palpitation or crepitus. For simple, isolated rib fractures, conservative treatment is usually adequate which includes appropriate analgesia, rest, and ice. The use of an incentive spirometer should be encouraged to prevent pulmonary atelectasis and splinting. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The image given in the question shows the fracture of upper end or proximal end of humerus.

questions.text: All of the following are true about oculomotor nerve palsy except:(AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Lateral and upward gaze

 

Lateral and upward gaze is a sign of trochlear nerve palsy, not of oculomotor palsy. Oculomotor nerve palsy leads to lateral and downward gaze.

 

Signs of oculomotor nerve palsy

 

  • Profound ptosis due to the weakness of the levator muscle
  • Abduction and depression in the primary position ("down and out") due to unopposed action of the lateral rectus and superior oblique muscles.
  • Intorsion of the eye at rest due to the intact superior oblique.
  • Limited adduction due to medial rectus weakness.
  • Limited elevation due to the weakness of the superior rectus and inferior oblique.
  • Limited depression due to the weakness of the inferior rectus.
  • Dilated pupil and defective accommodation due to parasympathetic palsy.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ptosis Occurs due to paralysis of the levator palpebrae superioris muscle, which is innervated by the oculomotor nerve.

 

Option B. Mid-dilated pupil: Results from paralysis of the sphincter pupillae muscle, leading to unopposed dilation by the sympathetic innervation.

 

Option C. Loss of light reflex: Occurs because the parasympathetic fibers controlling pupillary constriction are affected.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 Oculomotor nerve palsy typically causes an "down and out" gaze due to the unopposed action of the lateral rectus and superior oblique muscles, not a "lateral and upward" gaze, which would instead suggest trochlear nerve involvement.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is associated with hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis with hypertension? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Liddle syndrome

 

Liddle syndrome is a genetic disorder characterized by the overactivation of the epithelial sodium channels (ENaC) in the principal cells of the kidneys. This overactivation is due to a gain-of-function mutation in the genes encoding these channels. The increased activity of ENaC leads to excessive reabsorption of sodium and water, causing hypertension. Concurrently, there is increased excretion of potassium and hydrogen ions, which results in hypokalemia and metabolic alkalosis.

 

This condition is often referred to as pseudo-hyperaldosteronism because it mimics the effects of aldosterone but without elevated aldosterone levels. The treatment of choice for Liddle syndrome is amiloride, which directly inhibits ENaC channels, unlike spironolactone, which is ineffective in this condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bartter syndrome: Bartter syndrome also presents with hypokalemia and metabolic alkalosis, but patients typically have normal blood pressure. It is a group of autosomal recessive disorders that affect the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle, mimicking the effects of loop diuretics. Symptoms often present in childhood and may include polyuria, polydipsia, and growth delays. Additionally, patients might have nephrocalcinosis due to increase urinary calcium, recurrent urinary stones, and sometimes sensorineural deafness.

 

Option C. Gitelman syndrome: Gitelman syndrome, like Bartter syndrome, involves hypokalemia and metabolic alkalosis with normal blood pressure. It affects the distal convoluted tubule of the kidney, similar to the action of thiazide diuretics. Patients usually present in adulthood with symptoms such as muscle weakness, cramps, and tetany due to hypomagnesemia, which is a significant feature distinguishing it from Bartter syndrome.

 

Option D. Gordon syndrome: Gordon syndrome, or pseudohypoaldosteronism type II, is characterized by hypertension and hyperkalemia, along with metabolic acidosis, not alkalosis. It results from mutations leading to increased sodium chloride reabsorption in the distal convoluted tubule. Unlike Liddle syndrome, patients with Gordon syndrome exhibit hyperkalemia and acidosis due to chloride retention.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Liddle syndrome is characterized by hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis and hypertension due to the overactivation of epithelial sodium channels in the kidneys.

questions.text: An individual who is experiencing vertigo but does not have hearing impairment has consulted an ENT surgeon. The surgeon proceeds with a diagnostic technique followed by a carefully executed therapeutic procedure. What is the diagnostic maneuver?(AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dix-Hallpike maneuver

 

Vertigo without hearing loss diagnosed by a positional maneuver is benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV). The diagnostic maneuver used in BPPV is the Dix-Hallpike maneuver and therapeutic maneuver is the Epley's maneuver.

 

Dix-Hallpike maneuver:

 

  • Gold standard for diagnosing BPPV. 
  •  Nystagmus has a short latency period of 2-20 seconds, lasts for less than a minute, and has a fixed direction towards the lower placed ear, and is fatigable.
  • Associated with vertigo.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hampton's maneuver: This is not a widely recognized or standard maneuver in the diagnosis or treatment of vertigo. It does not relate to any commonly accepted procedure in the management of vertigo in otolaryngology.

 

Option C. Epley's maneuver: The therapeutic maneuver is the Epley maneuver which repositions the otolith to the utricle/saccule from the posterior semicircular canal.

 

 

Option D. Simon's maneuver: Like Hampton's maneuver, Simon's maneuver is not a standard or widely recognized technique in the diagnosis or management of vertigo associated with BPPV or other inner ear conditions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Dix-Hallpike maneuver is specifically used for diagnosing BPPV by eliciting nystagmus induced by position changes.
  • The Epley's maneuver is used to treat the vertigo symptoms once BPPV is confirmed by the Dix-Hallpike test.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 47

choices.text: Immediate closed reduction under conscious sedation
MRI of the hip to assess soft tissue damage
Application of traction and delayed reduction
Hip arthroscopy to evaluate for intra-articular damage

questions.text: A 30-year-old male is brought to the emergency department after a high-speed motor vehicle accident. He complains of severe pain in his right hip and inability to move his leg. On physical examination, his right leg is shortened, internally rotated, and adducted. A radiograph confirms a posterior dislocation of the hip without any associated fractures. Neurovascular examination is normal. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Immediate closed reduction under conscious sedation

 

Explanation:

 

The patient presents with a posterior hip dislocation, a serious injury often resulting from high-impact trauma like a motor vehicle accident. The clinical presentation of severe hip pain, inability to move the leg, and the characteristic leg position (shortened, internally rotated, and adducted) is highly suggestive of this diagnosis. Radiographs confirm the dislocation without any associated fractures.

 

Posterior Dislocation of the Hip

 

  • This is the most common type of hip dislocation (90%). It occurs when the femoral head is forced out of the acetabulum posteriorly, often due to a force applied to a flexed knee while the hip is flexed and adducted, a classic mechanism in motor vehicle accidents ("dashboard injury").

 

Radiological Features:

 

 

  • The X-ray will show the femoral head displaced posterior to the acetabulum.
  • The lesser trochanter may not be visible due to internal rotation of the thigh.
  • Shenton's line, a continuous arc formed by the inferior border of the superior pubic ramus and the medial border of the femoral neck, will be disrupted.
  • A CT scan is the most accurate imaging modality to assess the dislocation and associated fractures.

 

Treatment

 

  • Immediate closed reduction is the primary goal. The sooner the hip is relocated, the lower the risk of complications like avascular necrosis (AVN) of the femoral head, which occurs due to disruption of blood supply.

 

Closed Reduction Maneuvers

 

Several techniques are used, including:

 

  • Allis maneuver: The patient is supine, the hip and knee are flexed to 90 degrees, and traction is applied along the femur with simultaneous flexion, abduction, and external rotation.
  • Stimson's gravity method: The patient is prone, and the affected leg is allowed to hang over the edge of the table while gentle downward pressure is applied to the dislocated hip.
  • Bigelow's maneuver: The patient is supine, the hip is flexed, adducted, and internally rotated, and then traction is applied with simultaneous abduction and external rotation.
  • East Baltimore maneuver: A variation of the Allis maneuver with the patient in the lateral decubitus position.

 

Open Reduction

 

This may be necessary if:

 

  • Closed reduction fails, especially in delayed presentations.
  • There is an intra-articular loose fragment preventing reduction.
  • A large acetabular fragment from the weight-bearing part of the acetabulum is present, causing instability.

 

Complications:

 

  • Sciatic nerve injury: The sciatic nerve is vulnerable to injury during posterior hip dislocation.
  • Avascular necrosis (AVN) of the femoral head: Disruption of blood supply can lead to AVN, a serious complication that may require further surgery.
  • Osteoarthritis: Joint damage from the dislocation can accelerate the development of osteoarthritis.
  • Myositis ossificans: Heterotopic bone formation around the hip joint can occur.
  • Associated fractures: The femoral head, acetabulum, or other bones may be fractured.
  • Associated knee injuries: Ligament or cartilage injuries in the knee can occur due to the mechanism of injury.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. MRI of the hip to assess soft tissue damage: While MRI can be useful to evaluate soft tissue damage, labral tears, or other intra-articular injuries, it is not indicated as the initial step before reduction. Reduction should not be delayed to perform imaging that does not change immediate management.

 

Option C. Application of traction and delayed reduction: Applying traction and delaying reduction is inappropriate in this scenario. Early reduction is necessary to reduce the risk of complications and ensure better outcomes.

 

Option D. Hip arthroscopy to evaluate for intra-articular damage: Hip arthroscopy is not indicated in the acute setting of a dislocation without fractures. This procedure is reserved for cases with ongoing instability or intra-articular damage that does not resolve after reduction.

 

Educational Objective:


The immediate management of a hip dislocation without associated fractures is prompt closed reduction to prevent complications such as avascular necrosis and sciatic nerve injury. Delays in reduction increase the risk of long-term complications.

questions.text: Which part of 2nd metatarsal is involved in the march fracture?(AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Neck

 

MARCH FRACTURE

 

  • March fracture is a stress fatigue fracture of second metatarsal neck > 3rd metatarsal neck.
  • The second metatarsal is more prone to injury due to its limited motion from strong ligamentous attachment to the first and second cuneiforms and length compared to the other foot metatarsals.
  • They result from a sudden increase in the intensity, duration, and frequency of activity without sufficient rest.
  • The repetitive impact on the metatarsals with weight-bearing exercises causes microfractures, which consolidate into stress fractures and are not the result of a single traumatic event.

 

 

  • Common Fracture Eponyms:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The march fracture involves the neck of the 2nd metatarsal followed by 3rd metatarsal.
  • It is a stress fracture of the metatarsal.

questions.text: A patient presenting with multiple humeral shaft fracture, following which he had difficulty in flexion of elbow and supination of forearm. He also complaints of loss of sensation over lateral side of forearm. Which nerve is damaged?  (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Musculocutaneous nerve

 

MUSCULOCUTANEOUS NERVE (C5, 6, 7)

 

  • It is one of the two terminal branches of the lateral cord, the other being the lateral root of the median nerve.
  • It supplies coracobrachialis, both heads of biceps brachii and most of branchialis, and continues as the lateral cutaneous nerve of forearm, running down the lateral aspect of the forearm.
  • Injury to the musculocutaneous nerve results in weakness of supination (biceps) and flexion (biceps, brachialis, and coracobrachialis) of the forearm and loss of sensation on the lateral side of the forearm.
  • It is damaged in shoulder dislocation, second common to axillary nerve.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Median nerve. Median nerve injury is associated with a fracture of the humerus, especially supracondylar fractures. Entrapment at the elbow between the two heads of pronator teres (pronator teres syndrome) and under the flexor retinaculum (carpal tunnel syndrome) are also the causes. Median nerve injury at elbow level causes paralysis of forearm pronators. This keeps the forearm in supine position. When long flexors (except FCU and medial ½ of FDP) are paralyzed, the wrist flexion becomes weak and is accompanied by adduction due to paralysis of FCR and intact FCU.
