Flexion of terminal phalanx of thumb is lost because of paralysis of FPL. Flexion of interphalangeal joints of index and middle fingers is lost, so there is a pointing index or positive Ochsner clasp or Benediction test.

 

Option C. Axillary nerve. Injured in fracture of surgical neck of humerus, shoulder dislocation (anterior and inferior) and intramuscular injections. There is deltoid muscle palsy, loss of rounded contour of shoulder – giving shoulder a flattened appearance and produce hollow inferior to acromion, weakness of abduction (15-90°), Teres minor palsy, and sensory loss over lower half of deltoid (regimental badge area).

 

Option D. Radial nerve. It is usually injured in fractures of shaft humerus, injection palsy, Saturday night palsy and Crutch palsy. In radial nerve injury, there is sensory loss in the area supplied by the posterior cutaneous nerve of forearm. Wrist, thumb and finger extension is lost i.e., wrist, thumb and fingers drop. Loss of extension of wrist is wrist drop; of thumb is thumb drop; of MCP joint of finger is finger drop.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Difficulty in flexion of elbow and supination of forearm, with loss of sensation over lateral side of forearm are the symptoms associated with musculocutaneous nerve injury.

choices.text: All are true
a, b and c only
a and e only
a, c and e only

questions.text:
Mention the true statement/s about digoxin toxicity:(AIIMS MAY 2019)

 

  1. Earliest manifestation of digoxin toxicity is gastrointestinal symptoms
  2. Nonspecific vision changes may be noted in digoxin toxicity
  3. Early toxicity may not correlate with serum levels
  4. Neurological symptoms may occur without corresponding cardiovascular changes
  5. Hypokalemia is associated with increased risk of toxicity
questions.solution:
Ans. A. All are true

 

  • Most common and earliest adverse effect of digoxin is nausea and vomiting (option a).
  • Most common arrhythmia seen in digoxin overdose is ventricular bigeminy.
  • Other adverse effects of digoxin include Gynecomastia and Vision defects (initially non-specific and later yellow vision): Option b
  • Early toxicity may not correlate with serum levels because Digoxin has very high volume of distribution (~450L); So when digoxin reaches heart the plasma concentration may not be high.: Option c
  • Hypokalemia increases the risk of toxicity as the binding site of digoxin and K+ are same on the Na+ K+ pump. So, normally K inhibits the binding of digoxin to Na K pump. When K is less (hypokalemia), binding of digoxin increases and toxicity can result.
  • However, Note that Digoxin toxicity causes hyperkalemia (due to inhibition of Na K pump, K+ cannot enter inside cells and remain in blood, hence hyperkalemia occurs).

 

Educational Objective:

 

All statements about digoxin toxicity, including the earliest manifestations, vision changes, correlation with serum levels, neurological symptoms, and the association with hypokalemia, are true.

 

Reference: - KDT 8TH/560

choices.text: Bar and boot plaster

questions.text: A 75-year-old patient suffers with extracapsular femoral neck fracture. What would be the most appropriate management option for her management?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Intramedullary nailing

 

INTRAMEDULLARY NAILING

 

  • Intramedullary Nailing is a surgical technique used to stabilize fractures by inserting a metal rod (nail) into the medullary canal of the bone.
  • Mechanism: The nail is inserted into the central canal of the femur and fixed with screws at the ends to stabilize the fracture.

 

 

  • It is generally used for femoral shaft fractures but can be applied to extracapsular femoral neck fractures in elderly.
  • Indications: Intramedullary nailing is effective for stabilizing long bone fractures and can be used for femoral neck fractures if the fracture pattern and bone quality are suitable.
  • Complications: There is a risk of complications including infection, nonunion, and poor functional outcomes if not done properly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Russell’s Traction: Russell’s Traction is a type of skeletal traction used to align and stabilize fractures, particularly in the lower extremities. This traction method involves applying a pulling force to the limb through a system of pulleys and weights. It can help in aligning fractured bones and reducing pain by immobilizing the affected limb. For elderly patients with extracapsular femoral neck fractures, Russell’s traction is less preferred due to delayed recovery as the traction does not allow early weight-bearing or mobility, which is crucial for elderly patients to prevent complications like pressure sores and deep vein thrombosis (DVT). The immobilization provided by traction alone might not adequately stabilize the fracture, leading to a higher risk of nonunion or malunion. Prolonged use of traction can lead to muscle atrophy and joint stiffness.

 

 

Option B. Bar and Boot Plaster: Bar and Boot Plaster is a type of external immobilization used for fractures, particularly in the lower limb. This involves applying a plaster cast to immobilize the fractured limb, often including a bar and boot to provide additional support and alignment. It is used for fractures where conservative management is appropriate, particularly in pediatric or less complex cases. For extracapsular femoral neck fractures in elderly patients, this method is generally not preferred due to inadequate stabilization. Prolonged immobilization can lead to complications such as muscle atrophy, joint stiffness, and pressure sores, especially in elderly patients who are already at high risk for these issues.

 

 

Option D. Hemiarthroplasty: Hemiarthroplasty involves replacing the damaged femoral head with a prosthetic component while leaving the acetabulum intact. It is often used to address both the fracture and any pre-existing joint degeneration. Hemiarthroplasty is often preferred for intracapsular femoral neck fractures in elderly patients due to immediate stability provided to the hip joint and allowance for earlier weight-bearing and mobility, which is crucial for elderly patients to reduce the risk of complications from prolonged immobility. The prosthesis can alleviate pain and improve functional outcomes compared to conservative management methods. The procedure has risks such as dislocation, infection, and prosthesis failure, but it generally provides better outcomes in terms of mobility and quality of life for elderly patients compared to non-surgical methods.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Intramedullary nailing, while useful for certain types of fractures, is generally the first choice for extracapsular femoral neck fractures in elderly patients due to the risks and potential complications associated with the procedure.
  • Cephalomedullary nailing is done in such cases.

choices.text: Knuckle bender splint; Ulnar Nerve Palsy
Dynamic cock up splint; Radial Nerve Palsy
Turn buckle splint; Volkmann’s Ischemic Contracture
Knuckle bender splint; Median Nerve Palsy

questions.text: Correctly match the statement regarding the splint shown in image:(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dynamic cock up splint; Radial Nerve Palsy

 

  • Cock-up splint is used for radial nerve palsy.

 

 

RADIAL NERVE INJURIES

 

  • Most common nerve damaged in human body.
  • Most common cause: Fracture of shaft of Humerus
  • Shaft of Humerus divided into 3 parts:
    • Upper 1/3rd
    • Middle 1/3rd
    • Lower 1/3rd: Radial nerve injured (50%)
       
  • Holstein Lewis sign: Radial nerve injury in lower 1/3rd fracture of shaft of Humerus
  • Paralysis of ECRL & ECRB will cause loss of wrist, thumb and finger extension, leading to Wrist drop.
  • Wrist drop occurs in low radial nerve palsy, which spares the elbow and wrist extension.
  • There is also loss of sensation over the dorsum of 1st web space.

 

 

 

  • Treatment:
    • Treatment is usually conservative, which includes analgesic medications like NSAIDs; corticosteroid injections; physiotherapy; and immobilization with cock-up splints for 2-4 weeks.
    • The patient recovers within 4 months.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Knuckle bender splint; Ulnar nerve palsy. Knuckle bender splint is a finger flexion splint which flexes the MCP joint of all digits without blocking the IP joint or wrist joint motion. it assists the intrinsic muscle weakness. It is used in cases ulnar nerve palsy (ulnar claw hand) and median nerve palsy.

 

 

Option C. Turn buckle splint; Volkmann’s ischemic contracture. Turn buckle splint is used to produce gradual stretching over the contracted joint. It is used to treat stiff elbow and Volkmann’s ischemic contracture.

 

 

Option D. Knuckle bender splint; Median nerve palsy. Knuckle bender splint is a finger flexion splint which flexes the MCP joint of all digits without blocking the IP joint or wrist joint motion. it assists the intrinsic muscle weakness. It is used in cases ulnar nerve palsy (ulnar claw hand) and median nerve palsy.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The given image in the question is a dynamic cock-up splint, which is used in cases of radial nerve injuries (wrist drop).

questions.text: A 60-year-old female underwent hip replacement. After 1 year, she developed fever and pain in the joint. Radiograph revealed loosening of prosthesis. The implant had to be removed. The histological image of the tissue adjoining the implant is shown below. What is the diagnosis?(AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Metallosis

 

  • The microscopic image shows multiple foci of extracellular metal deposits (seen as black deposits) surrounded by inflammatory cells, suggestive of metallosis.

 

METALLOSIS

 

  • Metallosis is a rare, potentially fatal complication after arthroplasty characterized by the deposition and build-up of metal debris in the soft tissues of the body, associated with metal-on-metal prosthetic devices, but it has also been described in non-metallic prostheses.
  • It is defined as aseptic fibrosis, local necrosis, or loosening of a device secondary to metal corrosion and release of wear debris.
  • It occurs due to metallic erosion and release of metallic debris products, which induce massive local cytokines liberation from inflammatory cells.
  • It can present with local/systemic symptoms and signs due to a chronic inflammatory host response.
  • The local effects have been described as pseudotumours or osteolysis.
  • The systemic effects are caused by an immunological response to metal debris, including constitutional symptoms such as nausea, vomiting and malaise, cognitive impairment, haematological abnormalities and neuromuscular changes.
  • Risk factor for the development of metallosis include female gender, bilateral implants, high doses of corticosteroids, renal insufficiency and a suppressed immune system.
  • Its histology is characterized by widespread lymphoplasmacytic and histiocytic infiltration around metal debris, foreign body giant cells, metal particles, extracellular metal deposits and intracytoplasmic debris in giant cells.
  • Treatment consists of surgical revision with replacement of the prosthesis components, complete surgical debridement of osteolytic lesions and bone grafting with allograft chips.
  • Complete removal of all metal debris is difficult and may result in extensive tissue damage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Melanoma. Melanoma, also known as malignant melanoma, is a type of cancer that develops from the pigment-producing cells known as melanocytes. Melanomas typically occur in the skin. In women, they most commonly occur on the legs, while in men, they most commonly occur on the back. About 25% of melanomas develop from moles. Changes in a mole that can indicate melanoma include an increase in size, irregular edges, change in color, itchiness, or skin breakdown. The primary cause of melanoma is ultraviolet light (UV) exposure in those with low levels of the skin pigment melanin. Those with many moles, a history of affected family members, and poor immune function are at greater risk. Diagnosis is by biopsy. Using sunscreen and avoiding UV light may prevent melanoma. Treatment is typically removal of the melanoma and potentially affected tissue (border around the melanoma) by surgery. In those with slightly larger cancers, nearby lymph nodes may be tested for metastasis. For those in whom melanoma has spread, immunotherapy, biologic therapy, radiation therapy, or chemotherapy may improve survival. 

 

Option C. Ochronosis. Ochronosis is named for the reddish-brown hue of tissue termed "ochre-like". It is inborn error of metabolism. Ochronosis is due to deposition of a phenolic compound – "alkaptons" polymerizing into connective tissue, leading to black urine disease called alkaptonuria. Inherited in an autosomal recessive fashion, alkaptonuria is an inactive gene, mapped on chromosome 3q21-23 coding for the enzyme homogentisate 1,2 dioxygenase (HGD). The result is systemic sequestration of homogentisate, that upon the decay to benzoquinone, can irreversibly bind with collagen. Polymerization of this molecule takes on an iridescent dark hue, tinting affected tissue and turning urine black. Aside from just discoloration, these processes can cause degradation, degeneration, and developmental problems in all types of collagen. The earliest sign is from parents who notice infants’ diapers are black in color. This disease can be insidious and manifest later in life. Patients may present with back pain or large joint arthralgias in their post-teenage years or early 30s. Pigmentation of the sclera and pinna of the ear is often seen later in life. Constant tendon ruptures especially with minimal trauma. On physical examination, thickened Achilles tendon and bursa effusions are common. For alkaptonuria, a chromatography assay in the urine for homogentisate can be diagnostic, especially, if the color change is noted after being exposed to the air. A genetic test can determine the existence of the autosomal recessive disease.

 

Option D. Rosai-Dorfman syndrome. Rosai-Dorfman disease is a disease that occurs when the body produces too many histiocytes in the lymph nodes. These histiocytes accumulate in the cervical nodes most commonly. Histiocytes may also build up in the skin, upper respiratory tract, and sinuses. Rosai-Dorfman disease is seldom life-threatening. In many instances, the patient’s symptoms resolve on their own. The majority of patients experience enlarged lymph nodes on both sides of the neck. While often painless, these nodes can swell and grow rather larger. Swelling may also be reported in the lymph nodes of the groin, armpits, and in the central portion of the chest. This swelling may be accompanied by fever. The diagnosis is made following a tissue biopsy from the affected site. Though it is most commonly diagnosed in the first 10 years of life, it is also found in adults, affecting men and women equally. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The image in the question shows extracellular metal deposits (black deposits) surrounded by inflammatory cells, suggestive of metallosis.
  • It is associated with metal-on-metal prosthetic devices.

questions.text: A patient came to be emergency department with a radiograph showing posterior dislocation of hip. No associated fractures are seen. What is the next step in management? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Closed reduction

 

POSTERIOR DISLOCATION OF THE HIP

 

  • The head of the femur is pushed out of the acetabulum posteriorly. 
  • It is more common (90%)
  • Mechanism of injury:
    • The injury is sustained by violence directed along the shaft of the femur, with the hip flexed.
    • The occupant of the car is thrown forwards and his knee strikes against the dashboard. 
    • The axial load applied on a flexed knee placed in adduction.
    • The force is transmitted up the femoral shaft, resulting in posterior dislocation of the hip. It is, therefore, also known as dashboard injury.

 

 

  • Clinical features: 
    • The patient presents with a history of severe trauma followed by pain, swelling and deformity (flexion, adduction and internal rotation – FADIR), associated with a shortening of the leg.

 

 

  • Radiological features: 
    • The femoral head is out of the acetabulum. 

 

 

  • The thigh is internally rotated so that the lesser trochanter is not seen. Shenton’s line is broken.

 

  • Treatment:
    • In most cases, it is possible to reduce the hip by closed manipulation under general anaesthesia. 
    • Closed reduction is the primary and most urgent step in the management of an acute traumatic hip dislocation without associated contraindications. 
    • The sooner the reduction, the lower the risk of complications like AVN. 
    • Open reduction may be required in cases where:
      • Closed reduction fails, usually in those presenting late
      • If there is intra-articular loose fragment not allowing accurate reduction
      • If the acetabular fragment is large and is from the weight-bearing part of the acetabulum. Such a fragment makes the hip unstable.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Open reduction. Open reduction is done when closed reduction fails, usually in patients presenting late OR if there is an intra-articular loose fragment not allowing accurate reduction OR if the acetabular fragment is large and is from the weight bearing part of the acetabulum. Since the question states "No associated fractures are seen," and it's an acute presentation, open reduction is not the first line.

 

Option C. NCCT pelvis: A CT scan is very useful after closed reduction to check for concentric reduction, identify any occult fractures not seen on plain X-rays (especially small intra-articular fragments or acetabular wall fractures), and assess for incarceration of fragments. However, it is not the immediate next step before reduction in an uncomplicated dislocation, as delaying reduction to get a CT increases the risk of AVN. The priority is to reduce the hip.

 

Option D. Arthroplasty. Hip replacement surgery can be considered if optimal stability is not achieved with reduction and fixation of the associated injuries. It is a definitive surgical procedure, usually performed for severe arthritis or irreparable damage. It is definitely not the immediate next step for an acute hip dislocation in a patient who likely has no pre-existing severe joint disease and no associated fractures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The treatment of choice for posterior dislocations of hip is closed reduction/manipulation under general anesthesia in cases with no associated fractures.

questions.text: Which of the following tests are used for the evaluation of scoliosis?(AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bending forward

 

SCOLIOSIS

 

  • Scoliosis is characterized by lateral curvature of the spine associated with rotation of the involved vertebrae and classified by its anatomic location, in either the thoracic or lumbar spine, with rare involvement of the cervical spine.
  • Clinical Findings:
    • Scoliosis in adolescents does not typically cause significant pain.
    • If a patient has significant pain, she/he should be evaluated to rule out the possibility of some other disorder such as infection or tumor.
    • Deformity of the rib cage and asymmetry of the waistline are clinically evident for curvatures of 30 degrees or more.
    • Lesser curves may be detected through a forward bending test (Adam’s test), which is designed to detect early abnormalities of rotation that may not be apparent when the patient is standing erect.
    • Structural curve becomes more prominent on forward bending as opposed to postural scoliosis.
    • Rotation of the spine may be measured with a scoliometer.
    • Rotation is associated with a marked rib hump as the lateral curvature increases in severity.
       
  • Imaging:
    • Radiographs taken of the entire spine in the standing position in both the posterior anterior (PA) and lateral planes are the most valuable for diagnosis.
    • Usually, a primary curve is evident with compensatory curvature to balance the body.
       
  • Treatment:
    • Treatment of scoliosis depends on the curve magnitude, skeletal maturity, and risk of progression.
    • Specific management is dependent on the Cobb angle, measured on a standing PA X-ray of the spine.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Scoliosis curve evaluation is done by forward bending test/Adam’s test.
  • A structural scoliotic curve becomes more prominent on forward bending while the postural curve disappears.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis?(AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Giant cell tumor

 

GIANT CELL TUMOR (OSTEOCLASTOMA)

 

  • It is bone lesion of uncertain origin, most commonly seen in distal femur, proximal tibia, proximal humerus and distal radius.
  • Tumor of lower end radius is GCT till proved otherwise.
  • Most commonly seen in 20-40 years of age, after epiphyseal fusion.
  • There is a slight female predominance.
  • Histology: 
    • Multinucleated giant cells are seen on a background of stromal cells with little or no visible intercellular tissue.
    • The osteoclast giant cells are the malignant cells, which induce the proliferation of mononuclear macrophage – lineage cells, hence the dividing cell population is the mononuclear cells which form the matrix.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Most commonly presents with pain, with or without swelling.
    • Pathological fracture occurs in 10-15% of cases.
    • Pulmonary metastasis occurs in 4% of cases, but they usually regress spontaneously.
  • Investigations:
    • Eccentric lytic lesion at epiphyseal region, bounded by subchondral bone plate, with soap bubble appearance.
    • Biopsy is necessary for confirming the diagnosis.
  • Treatment:
    • Curettage and ‘stripping’ of the cavity, followed by swabbing with hydrogen peroxide or by the application of liquid nitrogen.
    • More aggressive tumors and recurrent lesions: Excision followed by bone grafting.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aneurysmal bone cyst. Aneurysmal bone cysts are locally destructive, blood-filled reactive lesions of bone and are not considered to be true neoplasms. Most commonly involves the lower limbs. Vertebral lesions, accounting for 15-20% of these entities, are located in the posterior elements. Radiographs reveal an expansile lytic lesion that elevates the periosteum, but remains contained by a thin shell of cortical bone. An aneurysmal bone cyst can have well-defined margins or a permeative appearance that mimics a malignancy. It is most often eccentrically located in the metaphysis. When differentiating between a unicameral and aneurysmal bone cyst using MRI, the presence of a double-density fluid level and intralesional septations usually indicates an aneurysmal bone cyst. Aneurysmal bone cysts are treated with extended curettage and grafting with a bone graft. Low-dose irradiation is effective; however, it is not used routinely because of the potential for malignant transformation.

 

 

 

Option C. Osteosarcoma. Osteosarcoma is a tumor characterized by the production of osteoid matrix by malignant cells. It is the second most common primary malignancy of bone behind multiple myeloma. Onset can occur at any age; however, primary high-grade osteosarcoma occurs most commonly in the second decade of life. All skeletal locations can be affected; however, most primary osteosarcomas occur at the sites of the most rapid bone growth, including the distal femur, the proximal tibia, and the proximal humerus. Almost all patients with high-grade osteosarcoma report progressive pain. Night pain may be an important clue to the true diagnosis. Periosteal reaction may take the form of “Codman’s triangle”, or it may have a “sunburst” or “hair on end” appearance. It is highly radio-resistant and ideally treated by chemotherapy followed by limb salvage surgery/amputation followed by chemotherapy.

 

 

Option D. Osteoblastoma. Osteoblastoma is an uncommon benign bone-forming neoplasm. Osteoblastoma commonly arises in the posterior elements of the spine and the sacrum. Other common locations include the mandible and long tubular bones (lower > upper extremities), where it is usually observed in the metadiaphysis. It affects mainly adolescents and young adults (mean age, 20 years) with a male predominance (2.5 to 1). The more aggressive forms are generally seen in slightly older patients, with a mean age of 33 years. Osteoblastoma less commonly involves the tarsal bones (talus and calcaneum). Like osteoid osteoma, osteoblastoma can be cortical, medullary, or rarely periosteal in a bone location. Like osteoid osteomas, osteoblastoma demonstrates marked new bone formation, although this process is generally more exuberant in osteoblastoma, which also tends to be more vascularized lesions. The nidus within osteoblastoma tends toward less organized osteoid and trabecular bone, less abundant nerve fibers, and lacks prostaglandins. They usually show aggressive behaviour with extensive uncontrollable local recurrence. Malignant transformation and metastatic diseases have been reported with osteoblastoma. On imaging, osteoblastoma lesions are most often radiolucent, round to oval, with well-defined margins and reactive sclerosis. Blown-out expansile lesion mimicking an aneurysmal bone cyst is appreciated in lesions of the axial skeleton.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The given image shows a Giant Cell Tumor of the distal end of radius.

questions.text: Which infection contracted in pregnancy won't be teratogenic?(INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) HSV 2

 

Explanation:

 

Herpes Simplex Virus type 2 (HSV 2) primarily causes genital infections and is not generally teratogenic. It poses risks primarily at delivery if there is an active infection, leading to neonatal herpes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rubella: Rubella is highly teratogenic, especially if contracted in the first trimester.

 

Option B. Cytomegalovirus (CMV): Cytomegalovirus (CMV) is a common cause of congenital infections and can result in severe fetal abnormalities.

 

Option D. Chicken pox: Chickenpox (Varicella) can lead to congenital varicella syndrome, which is teratogenic.

 

Educational objective:

 

Among the listed infections, HSV 2 is not considered teratogenic, although it requires careful management to prevent neonatal transmission during delivery.

questions.text: Which of these characteristics is not linked to superior semicircular canal dehiscence syndrome?(AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sensorineural hearing loss

 

  • Conductive hearing loss is seen in superior semicircular canal dehiscence syndrome (SSCDS).
  • “Third window” mechanism due to SCD and enlarged vestibular aqueduct. Schematic representations illustrate inner ear volume velocity with arrows -
    1. Normal anatomy allows volume velocity across the cochlear partition from the oval to the round window (two windows).
    2. Air conducted sound stimulation results in volume velocity from the stapes to be shunted toward the SCD (third window) and away from the cochlea, resulting in increased air-conduction thresholds at low frequencies and/or sound-induced vertigo (Tullio's phenomenon). Positive static pressure in the middle-ear cavity may result in ampullofugal fluid motion exciting the ampulla, resulting in nystagmus (Hennebert sign) and oscillopsia/vertigo.
    3. Elevated intracranial pressure from Valsalva against closed glottis (e.g., straining, heaving lifting) may result in ampullopetal endolymphatic fluid motion, inhibition of the ampulla, also leading to nystagmus (Hennebert sign) and oscillopsia/vertigo.
    4. Enlarged vestibular aqueduct (EVA) can also act as a third window, shunting volume velocity away from the cochlear partition and toward the widened vestibular aqueduct.

 

Gaze-evoked tinnitus or hyperacusis may also be seen.

 

 

  • High-resolution CT is the gold standard for identification of SSCD
  • Cervical VEMP sensitivity and specificity for diagnosing SSCDS ranges from 80% to 100%
  • Surgery is indicated only if symptoms are severe and disabling. Otherwise managed conservatively with medication.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gaze dependent nystagmus: This can occur in SSCDS due to the abnormal transmission of fluid pressure waves through the "third window" created by the dehiscence, affecting the balance organs in the inner ear.

 

Option B. Positive Fistula test: This test, which involves applying pressure to the ear canal, can produce eye movements (nystagmus) or vertigo in cases of SSCDS due to the abnormal transmission of pressure to the inner ear.

 

Option D. Positive Tullio's phenomenon: This refers to sound-induced vertigo or nystagmus, which is a hallmark of SSCDS. The phenomenon occurs because sound vibrations lead to abnormal fluid dynamics in the inner ear due to the dehiscence.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In SSCDS, conductive hearing loss is typical due to the additional pathway for sound and pressure transmission created by the dehiscence, not sensorineural hearing loss, which involves damage to the hair cells in the cochlea or the auditory nerve. Understanding these distinct characteristics helps in accurately diagnosing and managing the condition.

 

Ref - Scott Brown 8th edition, volume 2, Page no. 843-847

questions.text: Which of the following is not a type of subcortical dementia?(INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pick's disease

 

To approach this question, we need to differentiate between cortical and subcortical dementias.

 

This is a type of frontotemporal dementia and is cortical. It primarily affects the frontal and temporal lobes. Memory may be preserved in the early stages, but personality and language changes are prominent. Therefore, it doesn't fall under the subcortical category, making it the correct answer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Parkinson's disease: Parkinson's primarily affects the basal ganglia in the brain, which is a subcortical structure. The primary symptoms are motoric (tremor, rigidity, bradykinesia), but dementia can develop in the later stages of the disease.

 

Option C. Huntington's disease: This is a genetic disorder that affects the basal ganglia, especially the caudate nucleus, which is also a subcortical structure. Cognitive decline and psychiatric symptoms are common.

 

Option D. Wilson's disease: This is a genetic disorder that leads to copper accumulation in the body, including the brain. The basal ganglia is one of the primary areas affected, making the dementia subcortical in nature.

 

Given the options, Pick's disease is the only cortical dementia, making it the correct answer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Reference: A Short Textbook of Psychiatry, 7th edition, Page No 24.

choices.text: Post mortem lividity

questions.text: The postmortem change seen in the image below corresponds to which of the following?(AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Marbling

 

Explanation: In the above picture superficial veins are visible on the dead body which is characteristic of Marbling. Hydrogen sulphides gas produced by decomposing tissues combine with Hb to form sulph-meth-haemoglobin. This sulph-meth-haemoglobin stains the tissues and vessels producing a greenish black color called marbling.

 

 

Other options

 

Option B) Algor mortis: Algor mortis refers to the postmortem cooling of the body. After death, the body temperature gradually decreases until it reaches the ambient temperature hence this option is incorrect.

 

Option C) Rigor mortis: Rigor mortis is the stiffening of muscles that occurs after death due to ATP depletion in the muscles.

 

Option D) Post mortem lividity is a passive process of blood accumulating within the blood vessels in the dependent parts of the body as a result of gravity, causing a discoloration of the skin that varies from pink to dark purplish. The pale looking areas on the skin are the pressure areas. The below image of PM Lividity

 

 

Educational Objective

 

Marbling

 

  1. Marbling is a characteristic color change occurring in Putrefaction in which the superficial veins become visible on the skin due to staining by Hemoglobin or sulphmethhaemoglobin
  2. Mechanism of color change in putrefaction:
  1. Direct staining by Hemoglobin (Hb): Lyses of RBCs occur in putrefaction which releases the Hb. This Hb itself stains the tissues and vessels producing a reddish brown coloration which later becomes greenish black.
  2. Staining by Sulph-meth-haemoglobin: Hydrogen sulphides gas produced by decomposing tissues combine with Hb to form sulph-meth-haemoglobin. This sulph-meth-haemoglobin stains the tissues and vessels producing a greenish black color.
  1. This greenish black staining of superficial veins appears as prominent lines on the skin called Marbling
  2. Marbling is distinctly appreciable in the superficial veins of abdomen, shoulders, chest and inguinal region.
  3. Marbling starts in 24 hours and becomes prominent in about 36–48 hours after death in summer

questions.text: In spine straightening surgeries, screws used for fixation are inserted through which of the following parts of the vertebra? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pedicle

 

  • Spinal instrumentation (rods,  screws, hooks, etc.) are applied to the region of the spine to be corrected through transpedicular route and bone graft is added. 

  • In the spine straightening surgery, to stabilize the spine, screws are placed on the pedicles of the vertebral bone. 

 

 

  • Hooks may also be used in conjunction with screws, and are placed around the pedicle or around the lamina.

  • Rods are then secured in the screw heads, connecting adjacent vertebrae. 

  • The rods are shaped to match the desired corrected curvature of the spine, and are attached to the screws and/or hooks.

  • Bone graft material is placed around the final assembly and as the spine heals, spinal fusion is accomplished by bone growth between the vertebrae. This bone growth permanently fixes the spine in the desired position. The implants hold the spine in the corrected position while the spine fuses.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pedicle of the vertebra is the area used to fixate the screws through during the spine straightening surgeries for scoliosis.

questions.text: An 18-year-old girl with the diagnosis of acute promyelocytic leukemia was treated medically. She developed fever and tachypnea and a chest X-ray showed pulmonary infiltrates. What drug should she be given next? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dexamethasone

 

APML is a leukemia with excellent prognosis managed with Arsenic trioxide and All-Trans retinoic acid. Differentiation syndrome is characterized by infiltrates, pleural effusion after treatment and improves with Dexamethasone. Used Intrathecally in children for AML.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cytarabine is used in the treatment of acute myeloid leukemia.

 

Option C. Doxorubicin is a cardiotoxic drug used in Hodgkin, CA breast, thyroid.

 

Option D. Methotrexate is not recommended in APML treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dexamethasone is used to manage differentiation syndrome in patients with acute promyelocytic leukemia, characterized by symptoms like fever, tachypnea, and pulmonary infiltrates following treatment with specific leukemia drugs.

 

Reference -Harrison/Oncology/Acute leukemia/chap100-743

questions.text: Given below is the X-ray of proximal femur in a patient with pain hip. The deformity shown is:(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Shepherd crook deformity

 

FIBROUS DYSPLASIA

 

  • Fibrous dysplasia is a developmental anomaly of bone formation.
  • The hallmark is replacement of normal bone and marrow by fibrous tissue and small woven spicules of bone.
  • Fibrous dysplasia can occur in the epiphysis, metaphysis, or diaphysis.
  • It may affect one bone (monostotic form) or several bones (polyostotic form).
  • The monostotic form is the most common and is usually diagnosed in patients between 20 and 30 years of age. It most commonly affects the femur.
  • The polyostotic form typically manifests in children <10 years of age and may progress with age. It most commonly affects the maxilla and other craniofacial bones.
  • McCune-Albright syndrome refers to polyostotic fibrous dysplasia, cutaneous pigmentation (café au lait spots), and endocrine abnormalities (Precoceous puberty).
  • The cafe au lait spots have characteristically irregular ragged borders (commonly called “coast of Maine” borders).
  • Fibrous dysplasia of proximal femur has shepherd crook deformity.
  • Radiographic Findings:
    • In long bones, the fibrous dysplastic lesions have ground-glass appearance.

 

 

  • Shepherd crook deformity (looks like shepherds stick which is crooked in shape) bone is replaced by fibrous tissue in fibrous dysplasia.

  • The multiloculated translucent lesion may be surrounded by a sclerotic rim, called ‘Rind sign’.

     

 

A. Shepherd Crook deformity; B. Rind sign 

 

  • Involvement of facial bones may create a leonine appearance (leontiasis ossea).
    • On biopsy, Chinese Letter Pattern is recognised.
    • Surgical treatment (Curettage + bone grafting) is indicated when significant deformity or pathological fracture occurs or when significant pain exists.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Blade of grass deformity. The blade of grass sign, also called the candle flame sign, refers to the lucent leading edge in a long bone seen during the lytic phase of Paget disease of bone. The lytic, or incipient active, phase of the disease is characterized by intense osteoclastic activity that is exhibited on radiographs as osteolysis. In the long bones, osteolysis is manifested as a characteristic metaphyseal to diaphyseal wedge-shaped area of radiolucency that assumes the configuration of a flame or blade of grass. This advancing wedge of osteolysis, which begins in the subchondral bone of the epiphysis and extends peripherally into the metaphysis and diaphysis, spreads about 1 cm per year and shows no marginal sclerosis. A potential pitfall is misdiagnosing the track sign of the femur as the blade of grass sign.

 

 

Option C. Chicken wire appearance. Histopathologically, cellular areas in chondroblastoma are composed of “chondroblasts” with an oval to round nucleus and with well-defined eosinophilic cytoplasm. A fine network of pericellular calcification called “chicken wire calcification” are seen in the cytoplasm or stroma some cases.

 

 

Option D. Corduroy appearance. Hemangioma is a common benign bone lesion. It is estimated that 10% of the population has asymptomatic hemangioma of the vertebral bodies. Hemangiomas also are common in the skull. They usually are discovered as incidental findings. The radiographic appearance in the spine usually is characteristic, with thickened, vertically oriented trabeculae giving the classic “jailhouse” (Corduroy) appearance. In cross-section, these thickened trabeculae have a “polka dot” pattern on CT scan.

 

Treatment usually is not necessary.

 

 

Polka dot appearance on CT scan

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Shepherd crook deformity is seen in cases of fibrous dysplasia. It is commonly seen deformity with the involvement of femur.

questions.text: A 75-year-old male after a fall in bathroom had hip fracture as seen in the pelvic X-ray below. What will be the position of the left lower limb?(AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Shortened and externally rotated

 

HIP FRACTURE

 

  • The given image in the question shows a displaced femoral neck fracture.
  • Femoral neck fractures are a specific type of intracapsular hip fracture.
  • Femoral neck fractures are associated with low energy falls in the elderly.
  • In younger patients, the cause is usually secondary to high-energy trauma such as fall from a substantial height or motor vehicle accidents. 
  • Risk factors for femoral neck fractures include female gender, decreased mobility, and low bone density.
  • 70% of all hip fractures occur in women. 
  • Symptoms include pain in the groin or pain referred along the medial side of the thigh and knee in an impacted fracture.
  • In a displaced fracture, there will be pain in the entire hip. 
  • In an impacted fracture, there is no obvious clinical deformity on examination. There is mild discomfort in the active/passive hip range of motion, and pain with percussion over the greater trochanter.
  • In displaced fractures, the leg appears in external rotation and abduction deformity with shortening of the limb.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The given image shows a displaced femoral neck fracture in the elderly patient.
  • Following the fracture, the limb appears shortened with external rotation and abduction deformity at the hip.

choices.text: March fracture – 2nd and 3rd metatarsals
Boxer's fracture – 4th and 5th metacarpals

questions.text: A 29-year-old male soldier presents to the clinic with complaints of worsening foot pain that began after an intensive training camp. The pain is described as dull and located on the top of the midfoot, which worsens with prolonged standing and marching. He also reports the pain persists even at rest. Upon examination, there is tenderness over the dorsum of the foot. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. March fracture – 2nd and 3rd metatarsals

Explanation:


COMMON FRACTURE EPONYMS
 

 

 

March fracture:

 

  • Fatigue/stress fracture of the neck of 2nd and 3rd metatarsals.
  • More common in neck of 2nd metatarsal than 3rd metatarsal.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Bennett fracture – Intra-articular fracture dislocation of base of 1st metacarpal.

 

  • Shaft is laterally dislocated by the unopposed pull of the abductor pollicis longus.
  • The medial projection of the thumb metacarpal base on which the volar oblique ligament attaches, remains in place.

 

 

Option C. Jones fracture – Avulsion fracture at the base of 5th metatarsal at the metaphysio-diaphyseal junction.

 

 

Option D. Boxer's fracture – Fracture through the neck of 5th metacarpal.

 

More common in boxers

 

 

 

Educational Objective:


March fractures are stress fractures commonly involving the 2nd and 3rd metatarsals due to repetitive stress or impact activities. Recognition of this injury pattern in athletes or individuals with increased physical activity is essential for appropriate management and recovery,

questions.text: A child presented with pain in the forearm following a trauma. The radiograph of the forearm reveal the findings as shown. What is the most likely diagnosis?(AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Galeazzi fracture

 

Explanation:

 

GALEAZZI FRACTURE-DISLOCATION

 

  • Fracture of distal third of radius with dislocation of the distal radioulnar joint, along with damage to interosseous membrane and triangular fibrocartilage complex
  • A treatment regimen of closed reduction and cast immobilization has a high rate of unsatisfactory results.
  • Open reduction and internal fixation with plate is the treatment of choice in adult.

 

 

Monteggia and Galeazzi Fractures:

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Colle’s fracture. Colles’s fracture is fracture of lower end of radius at its corti-cocancellous junction mostly occurring in post-menopausal osteoporotic elderly women, as a result of fall on outstretched hand, with wrist in extension. It is one of the most common fractures in elderly. Most Colles fractures can be successfully treated nonoperatively, and cast (hand-shaking cast) is applied on opposite forces to displacement. Complications include finger stiffness (most common), malunion (2nd most common) leading to dinner fork deformity. Colles’s fracture is the commonest cause of Sudeck's dystrophy in upper limb.

 

Dinner fork deformity

 

 

Reduction and application of Hand-shaking cast

 

Option B. Smith’s fracture. A Smith fracture is a break to the end of the radius. The end part of the bone, which forms part of the wrist joint, is displaced or angled in the direction of the palm of the hand. Often, this injury occurs by a fall to the back of a flexed wrist but can occur in any fall to an outstretched hand. Smith fracture is treated by close reduction and immobilization in long arm (above elbow) cast with forearm in supination and wrist in extension (dorsiflexion).

 

 

Option C. Monteggia fracture. Fractures between the proximal third of the ulna and the base of olecranon combined with dislocation of the proximal radioulnar joint. The clue to successful treatment is to restore the length of the fractured ulna; only then can the dislocated joint be fully reduced and remain stable. In adults, treatment is reduction and fixation. In children, treatment is reduction and cast application. Posterior interosseous nerve has been most commonly injured nerve in association with Monteggia fracture dislocation because it takes a turn around radial head and is injured with its dislocation. This causes paralysis of thumb and finger extensors.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The given image in the question reveals a Galeazzi fracture of the forearm.

questions.text: Fracture at which site in leg will cause failure of dorsiflexion of foot? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Proximal fibular neck

 

COMMON PERONEAL NERVE INJURY

 

  • Trauma to the proximal neck of fibula leads to injury of the common peroneal nerve as the nerve winds around the neck of fibula.
  • The CPN injury causes paralysis of muscles of anterior and lateral compartments of the leg, namely tibialis anterior, extensor digitorum longus and brevis, EHL, peroneus tertius (deep peroneal nerve), peroneal longus and brevis (superficial peroneal nerve).
  • Paralysis of these muscles causes failure of foot dorsiflexion i.e., foot drop.

 

 

  • There is also sensory loss on the anterior and lateral sides of the leg, dorsum of the foot and toes, and medial side of the big toe.
  • Lateral border of the foot and lateral side of the little toe are unaffected (supplied by sural nerve, formed by tibial nerve).
  • Medial border of the foot and ball of big toe are also unaffected (supplied by saphenous nerve, branch of femoral nerve).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lateral malleolus: Fracture at the lateral malleolus is Danis-Weber type A fracture of the ankle. In this, there is fracture of the lateral malleolus distal to the syndesmosis. It is usually a stable fracture. It is generally below the tibial plafond, with an intact syndesmosis and deltoid ligament. This fracture does not cause any nerve injury; thus no ankle movement is affected. This fracture has a good prognosis with ankle secured in a splint or cast.

 

Option B. Proximal tibia: Fracture of proximal third of tibia is associated with anterior knee pain (cases operated with intramedullary nailing), non-union, malunion. No nerve is injured with this type of fracture.

 

Option D. Tibial shaft: Tibial shaft fractures rarely cause nerve injury. Surgical fixation of the fracture with plating puts the superficial peroneal nerve at risk. Saphenous nerve can be injured during placement of locking screws. Transient peroneal nerve palsy after closed nailing can cause EHL weakness and decreased sensation of first dorsal webspace.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Injury to the proximal neck of fibula causes paralysis of dorsiflexion of the foot because around this portion, the common peroneal nerve winds, which supplies the dorsiflexors of the foot.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with long standing history of back pain for 20 years and chest tightness. Lateral radiograph of the cervical spine is shown. What is the diagnosis?(AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) DISH

 

DIFFUSE IDIOPATHIC SKELETAL HYPEROSTOSIS

 

  • Diffuse idiopathic skeletal hyperostosis (DISH) is a spon­dyloarthropathy also known as Forestier’s disease or ankylosing hyperostosis.
  • It is a noninflammatory disease, with the principal manifestation being calcification and ossification of spinal ligaments and the entheses.
  • Diffuse idiopathic skeletal hyperostosis is characterized by florid hyperostosis of the spine.
  • Marginal bony proliferation leads to the formation of anterior osseous ridges that fuse and give the appearance of flowing wax on the anterior bodies of the vertebrae on radiography.
  • Ossification of paraspinous ligaments, such as the anterior and posterior longitudinal ligaments, may be seen.
  • The whole spine may be involved, and bony ankylosis occurs, although the disc spaces and facet joints remain unaffected.
  • The thoracic spine is most commonly involved, although the cervical and lumbar regions may also be affected.
  • Lesions are most prominent anteriorly and along the right lateral aspect of the spine.
  • Intervertebral disc spaces are preserved, unless there is co-existing lumbar spondylosis, and sacroiliac and facet joints appear normal. This helps differentiate diffuse idiopathic skeletal hyperostosis from spondylosis and the spondyloarthritis.
  • Diffuse idiopathic skeletal hyperostosis is usually seen in the middle-aged and the elderly.
  • In advanced stages, the disease may look like melted candle wax. The calcification and ossification is most common in the right side of the spine.
  • The distinctive radiological feature of DISH is the continuous linear calcification along the anteromedial aspect of the thoracic spine.
  • The disease is not fatal, however some associated complications can lead to death. Complications include paralysis, dysphagia, and pulmonary infections.
  • DISH has no indication of a genetic link, and does not affect organs other than the lungs, which is only indirect due to the fusion of the rib cage.
  • DISH may be discovered as a radiological abnormality, as mentioned above, without any symptoms.
  • Morning stiffness is also noticed in almost two-thirds of patients.
  • Calcification and ossification may be seen at peripheral entheseal sites, including the shoulder, iliac crest, ischial tuberosity, trochanters of the hip, tibial tuberosities, patellae, and bones of the hands and/or feet.
  • Treatment: NSAIDs can be helpful in relieving pain and inflammation associated with DISH.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ankylosing spondylitis. Also known as Marie-Strumpell or Bechterew’s disease. It is a seronegative chronic inflammatory disease affecting the spine and sacroiliac joints. HLA B27 is positive in 90% patients. Sacroiliitis is the earliest manifestation with features of both enthesitis & synovitis. It is most commonly seen in young males aged 15-25 years. Most common symptom is dull backache, insidious in onset, associated with morning stiffness for few hours that improves with activity. Question mark (?) posture due to hyperkyphosis of thoracic spine and loss of lumbar lordosis. Cervical spine involvement is usually late and show forward stooping and loss of extension and rotation. Anterior uveitis is the most common extra-articular manifestation. Spine radiograph shows loss of lumbar lordosis, haziness of SI joint margins (earliest change), calcification of supraspinous & interspinous ligaments (Dagger sign), Trolley/Tram-track sign i.e., three linear radiopaque lines due to ligament calcification, Bamboo spine appearance due to syndesmophytes.

 

 

Sacroiliitis

 

 

A. Trolley/Tram track sign; B. Bamboo Spine

 

 

Dagger Sign

 

Option C. Klippel feil syndrome. It is congenital fusion of one or more cervical vertebrae presenting with classical triad of limited neck motion, low hair line and short ‘web' neck (prominent trapezius muscle). Clinical features includes abnormal head position, true torticollis, restricted range of motion, without an obvious SCM contracture, congenital osseous fusions (synostosis) and failure of segmentation of the cervical spine.

 

 

Option D. Sprengel deformity. It consists of permanent elevation of the shoulder girdle due to developmental defect. The scapula is smaller in its vertical diameter and appears broad. It lies high in position. Para scapular muscles are composed of imperfectly developed muscle fibers or fibrous tissue. From the superior angle of scapula, a sheet or band like structure composed of fibrous tissue cartilage or bone extends upwards to attach to the transverse process of several cervical vertebrae, known as Omovertebral bar.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The given x-ray image shows DISH i.e., diffuse idiopathic skeletal hyperostosis, which is the non-inflammatory disease, with calcification and ossification of spinal ligaments and the enthuses, mainly at the thoracic spine.

choices.text: Bar and boot plaster

questions.text: An 80-year-old patient suffers with Intracapsular femoral neck fracture. What would be the most appropriate management option for her management?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hemiarthroplasty

 

INTRACAPSULAR FEMORAL NECK FRACTURE

 

  • Intracapsular femoral neck fractures (FNFs) account for approximately 50% of all hip fractures.
  • Intracapsular fractures demonstrate limited healing potential due to the absence of the periosteal layer, so the fracture is only immersed in the surrounding synovial fluid. 
  • These injuries occur secondary to low-energy falls in older individuals and higher-energy traumatic mechanisms in younger patients. 
  • However, most of these fractures occur in older people with underlying osteoporosis.
  • Displaced intracapsular femoral neck fractures in older people are typically managed with hip reconstruction procedures – the femoral head and neck are replaced with a reconstruction prosthesis.
  • These procedures include hip hemiarthroplasty or total hip arthroplasty (THA).
  • Non-displaced fractures may be managed with fixation using cannulated screw fixation.
  • Hemiarthroplasty, or femoral head replacement, is recommended for displaced intracapsular FNFs, especially in older patients with low activity levels.
  • THA is preferred for patients with intact ambulatory function or evidence of hip pain and degenerative arthritis.
  • Girdlestone resection arthroplasty (GRA) may be an option for patients who are unsuitable for hemiarthroplasty due to conditions like systemic infections or severe neurological impairment.
  • Hemiarthroplasty and THA are contraindicated in patients with an active hip infection.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Russell’s traction: This is a non-surgical method used for younger patients with femoral neck fracture with good bone quality. It might not be ideal for an 80-year-old due to potential complications from prolonged immobilization.

 

Option B. Bar and boot plaster: This non-surgical method also has limitations for elderly patients due to healing complications.

 

Option C. Intramedullary nailing: This surgical procedure uses nails to fix the fracture. While it can be an option, it might be risky for an 80-year-old's bone quality.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Hemiarthroplasty is a surgical procedure where the damaged femoral head is replaced with an artificial joint, preserving the patient's own socket.
  • This offers a good balance between pain relief, mobility, and surgical complexity for elderly patients with this type of fracture.
  • The most appropriate management option for an 80-year-old patient with an intracapsular femoral neck fracture is Hemiarthroplasty.
